In the U.S., political affiliation significantly impacts the choice of key foreign policy partners. While both Republicans and Democrats consider the UK their most important partner, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%) [2]. Democrats, on the other hand, prioritize Canada and Mexico more than Republicans do [2]. Despite these differences, both parties rank Germany similarly, placing it fifth among their top foreign policy partners [2, 3].
![Most important foreign policy partner for Americans based on Political Affiliation.](image8)

In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU, SPD, and Greens primarily name France as their most important partner, followed by the U.S. [7].

Regarding cooperation, American Democrats are more inclined to seek greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans are [12]. In Germany, CDU/CSU supporters are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than supporters of the Greens and SPD are [12].

![Level of desire of American and German political affiliations for cooperation with each other.](image3)

When it comes to Russia, Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration [10]. Preference for increased cooperation with Russia is higher among Republicans (41%) than Democrats (32%) in the U.S., and among Germans in the former East Germany (75%) compared to those in the former West (63%) [10]. About two-thirds of Democrats (66%) prefer close ties with Germany over Russia, compared with 57% of Republicans [11].
![Americans on if they would prefer close relations with Germany or Russia.](image1)

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence preferences for foreign policy partners and the desired levels of cooperation, with notable differences between parties and regions.

Americans and Germans differ significantly in their preferences for increased cooperation with Russia. Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to desire greater collaboration with Russia [3]. This preference is even more pronounced among Germans living in former East Germany (75%) compared to those in former West Germany (63%) [3].
![Americans Germans Both (VOL) Russia](image8)
In the U.S., Republicans (41%) are more inclined towards increased cooperation with Russia than Democrats (32%) [3].

When it comes to China, similar majorities in both the U.S. and Germany express a desire for more cooperation [2].
![Americans Germans Both (VOL) China](image8)
In Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to want greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [9]. In the US, Democrats are more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [9].
![Republican/Lean Rep Democrat/Lean Dem US. @ @ 63% 75% Germany () 100 CDU/CSU 57 Greens 45 SPD 47](image2)

In summary, Germans are more inclined towards cooperation with Russia than Americans, with a notable difference between East and West Germans, while Republicans in the U.S. show a stronger preference for cooperation with Russia than Democrats. Both countries show similar levels of support for increased cooperation with China, though political affiliations influence views on cooperation differently within each nation.

In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to favor closer ties with Russia than Democrats, with 31% of Republicans preferring close relations with Russia compared to 21% of Democrats [1]. Conversely, Democrats (66%) are more likely than Republicans (57%) to prefer close ties with Germany [1]. Increased cooperation with Russia is more commonly preferred among Republicans (41%) than Democrats (32%) in the U.S. [11].
![Americans](image7)
In Germany, there is significant support for a close relationship with Russia in the former East compared to the former West [10]. Nearly four-in-ten East Germans prefer close ties with Russia, while West Germans are twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. [10]. When it comes to China, Americans are almost equally divided, with 41% preferring Germany and 44% favoring China [9].
![Both (VOL) China](image2)
In terms of cooperation, Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [11]. Ideologically, conservative Americans and Germans on the right are more likely to view Russia favorably than their liberal and left-leaning counterparts [8].
![Germany- U.S.](image4)
In summary, political divides in both the U.S. and Germany significantly shape attitudes towards cooperation with Russia and China, with Republicans in the U.S. and East Germans showing a greater preference for closer ties with Russia, while views on China are more divided among Americans.

In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to favor increased cooperation with Russia (41%) than Democrats (32%) [8].

![Americans](image5)

In Germany, there are regional differences in attitudes toward cooperation with Russia. Those living in former East Germany (75%) show stronger preference for more collaboration, when compare to those in the former West (63%) [8].

![Both (VOL) Russia](image8)

Overall, political affiliations and regional differences, particularly in Germany, play a significant role in shaping attitudes toward cooperation with Russia.

Americans are more inclined than Germans to believe that military force is sometimes necessary [5]. Approximately eight-in-ten Americans believe it is sometimes necessary to use force to maintain order in the world, whereas only about half of Germans agree with this viewpoint [9].

![Agreement that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain order in the world.](image8)

In terms of defense spending, half of Americans believe that European allies should maintain their current spending levels [3]. The German public is divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of spending on national defense, with about four-in-ten taking each view [7].

![European and German defense spending preferences.](image6)

Despite differences in opinion on security issues, young people in both countries have more positive views of the U.S.-German relationship [11].

![Young people have more positive views on U.S. and Germany relations.](image3)

In summary, Americans are more likely than Germans to support the use of military force, and there are differing views on defense spending levels, but younger demographics in both countries view the U.S.-Germany relationship more positively.

Americans are more inclined to support military intervention than Germans [3]. Approximately eight-in-ten Americans believe that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain global order, whereas only about half of Germans share this view [3].

![Americans are much more likely than Germans to see use of military force as necessary to maintain world order](image6)

This difference in opinion extends to the use of military force in defense of NATO allies [11]. Six-in-ten Americans believe their country should defend a NATO ally against a potential Russian attack, while an equal proportion of Germans believe their country should not [11].

![Germans and Americans are on the opposite sides about defend NATO allies against Russia](image3)

Regarding defense spending, half of Americans think that European allies should maintain their current spending levels [12]. In Germany, public opinion is divided, with about four-in-ten supporting increased spending and another four-in-ten favoring maintaining current levels [9].
There is also difference between ideologies. Nine-in-ten American conservatives see military force as necessary, only 65% of liberals agree [1].

![Public split on necessity of military to maintain order](image1)

In the U.S., Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe [4].
The share among Republicans who think the U.S.’s European allies should increase their defense budgets has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [4].

![Increased defense spending in Europe saw more modest decline in this view among Democrats.](image7)

American and German opinions differ significantly on military intervention, with Americans more likely to support it, and on defense spending, with differing views on whether European allies should increase spending.

American and German opinions on defense spending have shifted over the years, with internal partisan differences influencing these views.

In the U.S., there's been a notable shift in opinion regarding European allies' defense spending. In 2017, 45% of Americans believed European allies should increase their defense spending [3]. However, by 2019, half of Americans felt that spending levels should remain the same [3]. This indicates a decreased emphasis on allies increasing their defense budgets.

Partisan divides exist within the U.S. on this issue [6]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe [9]. However, even among Republicans, the share favoring increased spending by European allies has fallen by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [9].

In Germany, the public is divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of defense spending [8]. About four-in-ten support each view [8]. This also marks a change from 2017, when about half of Germans were content with their country's defense spending [8].

Partisan gaps are also evident in Germany [11]. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of defense spending increases, while supporters of the Greens are more skeptical [11]. Members of the SPD fall in the middle [11].

In summary, American opinion has shifted towards favoring the status quo in European defense spending, while German opinion is divided between maintaining and increasing spending, with notable partisan differences in both countries.

In the U.S., there's been a shift in opinion regarding European defense spending. Half of Americans believe that defense spending levels in Europe should remain the same [7]. This is a change from 2017, when 45% of Americans thought their European allies should increase their defense spending [7].
![The image shows American and German opinions on whether their European allies and Germany should increase, keep the same, or decrease spending on national defense.](image4)
However, partisan differences exist. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents to favor increased defense spending in Europe [12]. Although, the percentage of Republicans who believe European allies should increase their defense budgets has dropped by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [12].
![The image shows opinions of Democrat and Republican on “Our European allies in Europe should increase their spending on national defense”.](image3)
In Germany, the public is divided on whether to increase or maintain current levels of spending on national defense, with about four-in-ten taking each view [3]. This represents a change from 2017, when about half of Germans were satisfied with their country's defense spending, and about a third felt it should be increased [3]. Partisan gaps also exist in Germany. Supporters of the CDU/CSU generally favor defense spending increases [1]. Supporters of the Greens are more skeptical, with only 28% wanting to raise defense spending [1]. Members of the SPD fall in the middle, with 41% saying Germany should increase defense spending [1].

In summary, American views on European defense spending have shifted towards maintaining current levels, while Germans are divided between increasing and maintaining their defense spending, with notable partisan divisions in both countries.

In the U.S., Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe [2]. However, support among Republicans for the U.S.'s European allies to increase their defense budgets has decreased by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [2]. This trend is visually supported by data showing a decline in the percentage of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals who believe European allies should increase spending on national defense from 59% in 2017 to 48% in 2019.
![The graph illustrates a decline in Republican support for increased defense spending by European allies from 2017 to 2019, while Democratic support remained relatively stable.](image7)
 In Germany, partisan gaps also emerge regarding defense spending [9]. The image below indicates that CDU/CSU supporters generally favor defense spending increases [9], The image support visually, while supporters of the Greens are more skeptical, and SPD members fall in between [9].
![The bar graph depicts the percentage of respondents who believe Germany should increase its defense spending, categorized by political party affiliation.](image8)
The divisions in opinion based on political affiliation show that views on defense spending are complex and vary significantly both within and between the two countries.

In conclusion, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence opinions on defense spending, with Republicans in the U.S. and CDU/CSU supporters in Germany generally favoring increases, although Republican support has declined over time.

In Germany, age plays a significant role in how people perceive the importance of U.S. military bases. Younger Germans, particularly those aged 18-29, tend to view these bases as less crucial for German national security. Approximately six-in-ten young Germans believe that U.S. military bases do not contribute to Germany's national security [10].
![Younger Germans doubt the importance of American military bases](image8)
In contrast, older Germans, especially those 65 and older, are more likely to see the bases as important, with 61% believing they are vital to Germany's defense [10, 1].

In the U.S., political affiliation impacts the view of who the most important foreign policy partners are [9].
![Perception of foreign policy partners based on political affiliation.](image1)
While both Republicans and Democrats value the UK as their most important partner, Republicans show a stronger preference for Israel compared to Democrats [9, 11]. Democrats, on the other hand, place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico as key foreign policy affiliates [9]. However, both Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. rank Germany similarly, placing it fifth on their list of most important foreign policy partners [9].

In summary, age differences in Germany significantly influence perceptions of U.S. military bases, with younger Germans being more skeptical, while political affiliations in the U.S. affect preferences for foreign policy partners, though views on Germany remain consistent across party lines.

There are significant partisan differences in the views on U.S. global engagement and the handling of international issues, particularly regarding the coronavirus outbreak [4]. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents largely praise the country's handling of the outbreak (71%), while a similar share of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are critical of it (73%) [11].

![Views of U.S. handling of coronavirus outbreak by party affiliation.](image4)

A majority of Democrats say the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems [3]. A divide exists within Democrats based on ideology: 64% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. should assist other countries, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [3]. In contrast, about three-quarters of Republicans prefer the U.S. to focus on its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [7].

![Preferences for U.S. involvement in global problems vs. domestic focus, by party affiliation.](image5)

Educational background also plays a role. More educated Americans are more critical of how the U.S. has dealt with the disease [10]. Those with higher levels of education are more supportive of helping other nations deal with their problems, while those with less education think the U.S. should first deal with its own problems [6].

In conclusion, views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues differ significantly across political affiliations, with Republicans generally favoring a focus on domestic issues and Democrats more inclined toward international cooperation, educational level with higher education correlate positively with support for global engagement.

Americans' perceptions of both the U.S.'s and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic are significantly influenced by their political affiliations, while educational background plays less role in their attitude toward China.

Partisan differences are stark when evaluating the U.S. response. A significant majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (73%) are critical of the U.S.'s response [7], with liberal Democrats holding even more negative views [7]. In contrast, 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents praise the country's handling of the outbreak [7]. This partisan divide is visually represented, showing a 44% difference between Democrats (27%) and Republicans (71%) who believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job [6].
![U.S. handling of the pandemic](image4)

Education has more influence on the perceptions of the U.S.' response. Around two-thirds of those with a postgraduate degree and six-in-ten college graduates believe that the U.S. has done a poor job [10]. While for those who have a high school degree or less think about the same is 43% [10].

On the other hand, majorities across all educational groups believe China has not handled the pandemic well [1]. However, there are significant partisan differences. Republicans are much more likely than Democrats to hold a negative view of China's response, with eight-in-ten conservative Republicans holding this view [9].
![China’s handling of the pandemic](image2)

In conclusion, political affiliation strongly influences perceptions of both the U.S. and China's pandemic response, while education level primarily affects views on the U.S. response and shows less impact on the perception of China's.

Americans' views on the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic by both the U.S. and China are significantly influenced by political affiliations [10]. Partisan differences are evident in how people perceive the effectiveness of the responses of both countries [7, 9].

Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to believe that the U.S. has done a good or excellent job in handling the outbreak (71%) compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (27%) [3]. This shows a clear partisan divide in the assessment of the U.S.'s response.
![Total](image3)

Conversely, views on China's handling of the pandemic also display partisan differences [9]. While a majority of Americans, are critical of China’s response [8], Republicans are much more likely to hold this view than Democrats [9]. Specifically, eight-in-ten conservative Republicans believe China has not handled the crisis well [9].

The partisan gap is wider when assessing the U.S. response compared to other countries [11].
![Rep-](image7)

In summary, political affiliation significantly influences the perception of how the U.S. and China handled the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans generally viewing the U.S. response more favorably and China's response more unfavorably compared to Democrats.

There's a significant partisan divide in the perception of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus. Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn "a great deal" from other nations [5, 8]. Specifically, 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. can learn a great deal, compared to only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners [5]. This difference is even more pronounced between liberal Democrats (67%) and conservative Republicans (25%) [8].

This difference in perception correlates with trust levels in international organizations. Americans’ views of how well the WHO has dealt with the coronavirus outbreak also fall along partisan lines [4].
![Trust levels for WHO, EU, and Chinese government across different political affiliations.](image3)
Democrats show higher trust in the WHO and EU than Republicans [4, 2]. For example, 86% of liberal Democrats trust information from the WHO at least a fair amount, while only 27% of conservative Republicans do [2].

Those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries are more likely to positively assess other nations' handling of the outbreak, regardless of political affiliation [3, 9].
![Views on how well select countries have handled COVID-19, based on whether the U.S. can learn from them.](image5)
The difference is larger between Democrats and Republicans.

In summary, Democrats are more likely to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus and have higher trust in international organizations like the WHO and EU compared to Republicans.

Americans' views on the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China vary significantly based on political affiliation and education level.

Regarding China, half of Americans believe its influence will decline after the coronavirus outbreak, while nearly one-in-five think it will grow, and about a third think its global standing will remain the same [12]. There's a notable partisan divide: roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China's international clout will diminish, compared to just 40% of Democrats [6].

When it comes to the U.S., the public is largely split [4].
![Americans are split on how U.S. influence will change after the pandemic.](image4)
About three-in-ten believe U.S. international clout will be bolstered, a similar share thinks it will weaken, and about four-in-ten foresee no change [4]. Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened [1]. Conversely, Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken [1]. Education also plays a role, with Americans who have completed higher levels of education being more likely to think the country's global influence will recede [10].
![Educational differences in views on U.S. influence.](image1)

For the EU, majorities from both parties believe its international influence will be unaffected by the coronavirus outbreak [3].
![EU influence.](image5)
Specifically, the percentage of those who say that EU have the same influence is 59% [8].

In summary, Republicans are more optimistic about the U.S.'s future influence and more pessimistic about China's, while Democrats are more pessimistic about the U.S.'s future and less so about China's, with education levels further influencing these views; however, both parties largely agree that the EU's influence will remain unchanged.

Americans are largely divided on how the pandemic will affect U.S. influence [8]. Approximately three-in-ten believe U.S. international influence will be boosted, a similar share think it will weaken, and about four-in-ten predict it will remain the same [8]. Educational background influences these views; those with higher education levels are more inclined to think the country’s global influence will decrease [9].

Predictions about China's global influence show significant partisan and age divisions [11, 12]. Republicans (about six-in-ten) are much more likely than Democrats (40%) to believe China’s international power will decrease due to the outbreak [12]. Older Americans (65+) are 16% more likely than younger adults (under 30) to foresee a decline in China's global influence [12].
![Americans have different views on China's influence.](image6)
Many Americans, 50%, believe that the pandemic will reduce China's global influence, an opinion reflecting the rising negative attitudes toward China [6]. In contrast, fewer people believe the U.S. or the European Union will experience a similar decline in influence [10]. While half of Americans believe China will emerge from the current crisis with less influence in world affairs [10].
![Republicans and Democrats have different views on whether China will have more or less influence.](image5)

In summary, predictions about global influence after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly, with Republicans and older Americans more likely to predict a decline in China's influence, while opinions on U.S. influence are more divided and influenced by education levels.

Americans generally view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively [9]. Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe China has not done a good job, with 37% saying the country has done a "poor" job [9]. This negative sentiment is further reflected in the rising unfavorable attitudes toward China [3].

Americans also predict a change of China's influence on the world stage, the majority believe it will decline after the coronavirus outbreak [11].
![Americans’ opinions on how much the U.S. is involved in solving global problems.](image8)

Partisan differences are significant in these perceptions [2]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to hold a negative view of China's handling of the outbreak [2]. Eight-in-ten conservative Republicans believe China has not handled the crisis well [2].
![Opinions of Americans by political affiliation regarding international relations and handling of the coronavirus.](image5)
Half of Americans believe that China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic [3]. There is a large partisan divide on this question: Roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China's international clout will diminish as a result of the coronavirus outbreak, while just 40% of Democrats say the same [5].
![Responses regarding China's handling of the coronavirus by political affiliation.](image2)

In summary, Americans largely disapprove of China's handling of the coronavirus and anticipate a decline in its global influence, with Republicans holding significantly more negative views than Democrats.

There are notable partisan divisions in opinions regarding the U.S.'s role in addressing global challenges and its international influence following the coronavirus outbreak.

A significant majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much in helping to solve world problems. ![Perceptions on U.S. involvement in solving world problems among Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals.](image3) In contrast, only 26% of Democrats share this view [7]. This partisan gap has widened considerably compared to previous Pew Research Center telephone surveys dating back to 2013, where the differences were more modest [7]. The trend from 2013 to 2020 show that the view of Republicans thinking US does too much has been growing. ![Perceptions on U.S. involvement in solving world problems among Total.](image1)

Regarding the U.S.'s international influence after the crisis, Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe it will be strengthened [4]. Conversely, Democrats are approximately four times more likely than Republicans to predict that American influence will weaken [4]. There's also an internal division among Democrats, with liberal supporters being 20 percentage points more likely than conservative and moderate Democrats to foresee a decline in U.S. international influence [4]. For example, regarding the view that the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs after the coronavirus outbreak, divided by political view shows that a much larger percentage of Liberal Democrat think so than Conservative Republican. ![Perceptions on U.S. involvement in solving world problems among different political groups.](image6)

In summary, Republicans are more likely to think the U.S. does too much globally and will emerge stronger post-pandemic, while Democrats are more inclined to believe the U.S. should do more and will see its influence diminish.

Americans exhibit significant partisan divisions in their perspectives on both the United States' capacity to learn from other countries and its role in international affairs during the COVID-19 pandemic.

A majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (60%) believe the U.S. can learn "a great deal" from other nations about how to slow the spread of the coronavirus, compared to only 28% of Republicans and Republican-leaners [11]. This difference is further illustrated by the breakdown of those who believe the U.S. can learn "a great deal": 67% of liberal Democrats hold this view, versus just 25% of conservative Republicans [5].
![A great deal/a fair amount](image2)

These partisan divisions extend to opinions about America's role in the world. A clear majority (60%) believe the U.S. should deal with its problems and allow other countries to handle their own matters [1]. However, 64% of liberal Democrats advocate for the U.S. to assist other nations, a view shared by a far smaller percentage of Republicans [9]. Specifically, only 22% of conservative Republicans and 24% of moderate/liberal Republicans think the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems [5].

The expectation of the U.S.'s future global influence also varies along partisan lines, with 56% of Liberal Democrats believe the U.S will have less influence, and only 8% Conservative Republicans think U.S will have less influence in world affairs [5].
