In summary, Democrats are significantly more likely than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries in handling the pandemic and are more inclined to support the U.S. taking an active role in helping other nations, while also anticipating a diminished U.S. role of influence on the world's stage after the outbreak.

Americans' views on whether the U.S. should prioritize its own problems or assist other nations vary significantly across political lines and educational backgrounds. A majority, 60%, believe the U.S. should focus on domestic issues and let other countries handle their own affairs [4]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans, with about 75% favoring a focus on domestic problems [11].

![60% of Americans say the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries handle theirs as best they can.](image6)

Conversely, more than half of Democrats believe the U.S. should assist other countries, although there's a notable ideological split within the party [6]. Specifically, 64% of liberal Democrats advocate for helping other countries, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [6].

![Liberal Democrats are more likely than Conservative/Moderate Democrats to support helping other nations deal with their problems.](image6)

Educational attainment also plays a role. Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should help other countries [3]. College graduates are evenly split, and majorities of those with some college or with a high school diploma or less say the U.S. should deal with its own problems [3].

In conclusion, views on the U.S.'s role in global affairs are heavily influenced by political affiliation, with Republicans favoring a domestic focus and Democrats, particularly liberal ones, more inclined to support international aid, and also differ based on educational attainment, with higher education levels correlating with greater support for helping other nations.

There is a significant partisan divide in the perception of the U.S.'s role in solving world problems, and this divide has widened over time.

A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems [2, 10]. This is visually represented by a graph showing an increase in this sentiment among Republicans from 37% in 2013 to 62% in 2020. ![Majority of Republicans now say U.S. does too much to solve world problems](image7) In contrast, only 26% of Democrats share this view [10]. A plurality of Democrats (48%) believe the U.S. does too little [2].

About three-quarters of Republicans prefer the U.S. to focus on its own problems and let other countries manage on their own [3]. This sentiment is also depicted in an image illustrating the breakdown of opinions by political affiliation and age groups. ![Opinions by political affiliation and age groups](image1)

Conversely, more than half of Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries [12]. Specifically, 64% of liberal Democrats advocate for U.S. involvement in solving other countries' problems, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [12]. The general trend since 2013 is that the opinions haven't changed much.
![Democrats' opinion from 2013 to 2020](image8)

In conclusion, perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems differ significantly by political affiliation, with Republicans increasingly favoring a focus on domestic issues and Democrats, particularly liberal Democrats, favoring international assistance, and these differences have become more pronounced over time.

There are significant partisan differences in the views on U.S. global engagement and the prioritization of domestic issues. A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems [1], and about three-quarters of Republicans want the U.S. to focus on its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [8].
![Republicans: U.S. does "Too much" to solve world problems, 2013-2020](image8)
In contrast, a plurality of Democrats (48%) say the U.S. does too little to help solve world problems [1].
![Democrats: U.S. does "Too little" to solve world problems, 2013-2020](image2)
More than half of Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, with liberal Democrats (64%) being more likely to hold this view than conservative and moderate Democrats (44%) [2].

Educational attainment also influences these views. Individuals with higher levels of education are more supportive of the U.S. helping other nations [3]. Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should help other countries, while college graduates are evenly split [3].
![Should the U.S. help other countries or focus on its own problems, by education level](image7)
Majorities of those with some college experience and those with no more than a high school diploma believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems [3].

In summary, Republicans and those with less education are more likely to favor the U.S. focusing on domestic issues, while Democrats and those with higher education are more likely to support U.S. engagement in solving global problems.

Americans express concerns about various issues in the U.S.-China relationship, with a significant portion identifying cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights as very serious problems [12]. About three-quarters or more say that each issue is at least somewhat serious [12].

The specific concerns that stand out as "very serious" for at least half of Americans are [12]:
*   Cyberattacks from China
*   The loss of U.S. jobs to China
*   China's growing military power
*   China's policies on human rights

These concerns can be seen visually:

![Concerns about China](image7)

Half of Americans now say China's policy on human rights is a very serious problem for the U.S. – up 7 percentage points since last year. And nine-in-ten Americans say China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [2]. The share who see the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem has increased by 6 points since 2020, to 53% [6].

Despite these significant concerns, Americans have relatively less faith in President Biden's ability to handle the China issue compared to other foreign policy matters [4, 9]. Around half of Americans (53%) have confidence Biden will be able to deal effectively with China [5]. This is visually demonstrated:

![Confidence in Biden's Handling](image6)

Americans have the least confidence in Biden on this issue among six that have been evaluated [5]. For example, 67% have confidence in him to improve relationships with allies [5]. There are also significant partisan divisions, with Democrats being much more confident than Republicans in Biden's ability to deal with China [7].

In conclusion, while Americans view several aspects of the U.S.-China relationship as very serious, their confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China is relatively moderate, and lower than their confidence in his handling of other foreign policy issues.

Americans' confidence in President Joe Biden's ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic groups [10]. Women (59%) express more confidence than men (48%). Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) show greater confidence than White adults (43%). Individuals with a college degree are more confident (60%) than those without (50%) [10].

![Confidence in Biden's Ability to Deal with China Across Demographics](image7)

Age also plays a role, although the provided data does not offer specific confidence percentages for each age group beyond the general observation about educational attainment [10, 5].

Americans express substantial concern about various aspects of the U.S.-China relationship. The primary concerns, with at least half of Americans describing these as "very serious," include cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights [12].

![Primary Concerns of Americans Regarding China](image8)

Other concerns, while still considered serious by a majority, are viewed as "very serious" by a smaller percentage of the population [3]. These include tensions between mainland China and Hong Kong, tensions between mainland China and Taiwan, the U.S. trade deficit with China, and China’s growing technological power [3, image1].

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to handle China is higher among women, Black and Hispanic adults, and college-educated individuals, while the main concerns Americans have regarding China are cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights policies.

Americans express varied levels of confidence in President Biden's ability to effectively handle China, with significant differences observed across demographics and political affiliations. Overall, about half of Americans (53%) express confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China [1].

Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%) in Biden's capability [11]. Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) show greater confidence compared to White adults (43%) [11]. Additionally, those with a college degree (60%) are more confident than those without one (50%) [11].
![Confidence in Biden's Ability to Deal with China](image3)

Partisan differences are particularly stark. A significant majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (83%) have confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China, whereas only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents share this view [3, 12].
![Party's Confidence in Dealing with China](image6)

Americans consider several issues in the U.S.-China relationship to be very serious. Among these, cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's policies on human rights stand out as the most pressing concerns [5, 7].
![Serious Problems with China](image8)
Americans also believe that China does not respect the personal freedom of its people.
![China’s Human Rights](image1)

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China varies significantly across demographic groups and is highly polarized along political lines, with Democrats expressing far greater confidence than Republicans. The most serious concerns regarding China include cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights policies.

Americans express varied levels of confidence in President Biden's ability to handle the China issue, with notable differences across demographic groups [7]. Women (59%) show more confidence than men (48%) in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China [7]. Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) also express more confidence than White adults (43%) [7]. Those with a college degree are more confident (60%) than those without (50%) [7].
![Confidence level by demographics](image8)
Partisan differences are significant [11]. While 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals have confidence in Biden's approach to China, only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals share this sentiment [11].

Americans have substantial concerns about various aspects of the U.S.-China relationship [12].
![Major Concern](image3)
The major concerns, where half or more Americans consider them "very serious," are cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's human rights policies [12]. Cyberattacks from China are the most concerning, with roughly two-thirds of Americans considering them a very serious problem [2].

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China is higher among women, Black and Hispanic adults, and college graduates, with a significant partisan divide, and major concerns regarding China include cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

Americans have distinct views on China's performance in different areas. Regarding the COVID-19 pandemic, a majority of Americans (54%) believe China has done a bad job in handling the outbreak [2]. This sentiment is further illustrated by the breakdown of opinions:
![Americans' opinions on how China is handling climate change.](image1)
However, Americans are similarly critical of their own country's handling of the pandemic, with 58% saying the U.S. has done a bad job [4, 10].
![Comparison of American opinions on the handling of COVID-19 by China and the U.S.](image7)

In stark contrast, when it comes to personal freedoms, a vast majority of Americans (90%) believe that the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [9]. This view is consistent across various demographics, indicating a widespread concern about human rights in China.
![Americans' opinions on whether China respects the personal freedoms of its citizens.](image6)

This negative perception of China's human rights record influences American priorities in the U.S.-China relationship. Americans believe that these factor should be addressed:
![Priorities of Americans about U.S. should do about relationship with China.](image4)

In conclusion, Americans view China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic negatively, but are similarly critical of the U.S. response, while an overwhelming majority believe China does not respect personal freedoms and want this prioritized in bilateral relations.

Americans, when asked whether the U.S. should prioritize economic relations with China or promote human rights in China, $70\%$ choose human rights, even if it potentially harms economic relations with China [6]. Democrats and Republicans largely agree on human rights-related issues [7].
![Prioritize economic relations, even if it means not addressing human rights issues](image3)
About seven-in-ten Democrats and Republicans say the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations between the two countries [1]. Some Americans mentioned “the oppressive measures it takes on those within its borders, especially the plight of Uyghur Muslims, but also the restrictions placed by the Communist government on free speech and dissent by its citizens" [2].

However, there are nuances within each party. Conservative Republicans are more likely to prioritize human rights over economic dealings in U.S.-China relations [1].
![Get tougher](image6)
When thinking about economic and trade policies with China, more Americans want the U.S. to get tougher with China rather than to focus on building a stronger relationship [10].
About six-in-ten Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents would rather focus on building stronger ties with China [10].

In conclusion, a majority of Americans across political affiliations prioritize promoting human rights in China, even at the expense of economic relations, although conservative Republicans show a stronger inclination towards this stance compared to Democrats.

Americans broadly favor prioritizing human rights in China, even at the expense of economic relations [7]. This sentiment is shared by approximately seven-in-ten Democrats and Republicans, indicating bipartisan support for emphasizing human rights [6]. However, there are nuances within each party. Conservative Republicans are more likely to prioritize human rights over economic dealings compared to their moderate or liberal counterparts [6].
![Prioritize human rights in China, even at the cost of economic relations.](image1)
Similarly, among Democrats, those who identify as liberal are the most likely to emphasize human rights [6].

When it comes to economic and trade policies with China, there's a divergence in views based on political affiliation. A majority of Americans want the U.S. to get tougher with China, rather than focusing on building a stronger relationship [12]. This view is particularly strong among Republicans, with 72% wanting a tougher stance, and even higher (81%) among conservative Republicans [12].
![Views on getting tougher with china vs building stronger relationship.](image7)
Conversely, about six-in-ten Democrats prefer building stronger ties with China, a sentiment consistent across the liberal and moderate/conservative wings of the party [12].

In summary, while both Democrats and Republicans largely support prioritizing human rights over economic relations with China, they differ on trade policy, with Republicans favoring a tougher stance and Democrats preferring to build a stronger relationship.

Americans' views on trade policies with China and their broader implications are heavily influenced by political affiliation. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents largely favor a tougher stance on China, with a significant majority (72%) expressing this preference [2]. This is further emphasized by the fact that about half of Republicans believe that increased tariffs on Chinese goods have been beneficial for the U.S [5]. Conservative Republicans are particularly strong proponents of both getting tougher with China [2] and viewing tariffs positively [5].

![Republicans largely stating it being good for US](image1)

On the other hand, Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents are more inclined to prioritize building a stronger relationship with China [2]. This sentiment is reflected in their view of tariffs, with a majority stating that increased tariffs on Chinese goods have been bad for the U.S [5].

![Democrats largely stating it being bad for US](image2)

However, despite differing views on economic policies, a notable consensus exists across party lines regarding human rights.

![Most republicans and democrats say that US should promote human rights in China](image4)

About seven-in-ten Democrats and Republicans believe the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [10].

In summary, Republicans generally favor getting tougher with China on trade and view tariffs positively, while Democrats prefer building a stronger relationship and view tariffs negatively, but both parties prioritize human rights in China, even at the expense of economic relations.

Americans have diverse views on tariffs and international students. Generally, a majority (80%) believe it is beneficial for U.S. colleges and universities to accept international students [11]. However, this view is nuanced when considering Chinese students specifically.

Partisanship significantly influences opinions on both tariffs and international students. Republicans are more likely to view increased tariffs on foreign goods, including those from China, as positive for the U.S. [4], as seen with about half of Republicans supporting these tariffs [4]. Democrats typically hold the opposite view, often perceiving tariffs as detrimental to the U.S [4].
![Republicans and Democrats differ on the impacts of tariffs.](image2)

Regarding international students, a majority of Americans (55%) support limiting the number of Chinese students studying in the U.S., with Republicans more likely to favor such limitations compared to Democrats [8, 12].
![A majority of Americans support limiting Chinese students, with partisan differences.](image5)
While at least two-thirds of both Democrats and Republicans see visiting students positively, there's a notable difference: 92% of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents hold this perspective, compared to 67% of Republicans and Republican leaners [1].

In summary, Republicans tend to view tariffs more favorably and are more inclined to support limits on Chinese students, while Democrats generally oppose tariffs and are more welcoming of international students, including those from China.

There are notable differences in opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities across age and political affiliation. Older Americans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students [7]. For example, roughly seven-in-ten Americans aged 50 and older favor such limitations, compared to nearly two-thirds of those aged 18 to 29 who oppose the idea [7]. A majority of Americans (55%) support limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S [8].

![Support and opposition for limiting Chinese students studying in the U.S., broken down by demographics, including age and political affiliation.](image4)

This difference in opinion based on age and political affiliation is also visualized in image, showing the "Oppose" and "Support" about "limiting Chinese students in the U.S" across demographic and partisan groups.

Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor limitations on the number of Chinese students [7]. This is reflected in the data, where 69% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents support limits, compared to 42% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents.
The data also shows Republicans are significantly more likely to have very cold feelings toward China, say the U.S. should get tougher on China on economic issues [4].

Confidence in Chinese leadership, specifically President Xi Jinping, also varies across age and political affiliation. Older Americans are more likely to have no confidence in Xi [10]. While 53% of those 65 and older have no confidence at all in Xi, only 35% of those 18 to 29 say the same [10].

![Breakdown of confidence levels in Chinese President Xi Jinping, categorized by demographics and political leanings.](image6)

Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents have slightly more confidence in Xi, with only a third saying they have no confidence at all [12].

In summary, older Americans and Republicans are more likely to support limiting Chinese students and express no confidence in Chinese leadership, while younger Americans and Democrats are less likely to support limits and have slightly more confidence in Xi.

American perceptions of China have become substantially more negative from 2018 to 2021 [9]. In 2018, 46% of Americans reported feeling "cold" toward China, and this figure rose to 67% by 2021 [7]. The intensity of these negative feelings has also increased, with the share of Americans reporting "very cold" feelings (0-24 on a feeling thermometer) towards China nearly doubling from 23% to 47% [1].

A significant concern is China's human rights policies. Half of American adults view this as a very substantial problem for the U.S., marking a 7-point increase since 2020 [5]. This concern is also frequently cited in open-ended responses, with one-in-five Americans mentioning human rights [10]. Specific issues like China’s treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang, which was labeled a “genocide” by the former U.S. administration, are emphasized [5].
![Human rights are a primary concern for Americans thinking about China.](image1)

Economic issues are also top of mind for Americans [11]. Many Americans mentioned China’s powerful economy, its dominance in manufacturing, and economic relations between the US and China [4]. Around two-thirds (64%) describe the economic relationship between the two countries as somewhat or very bad [4]. The loss of jobs to China is another major concern [8].
![Concerns regarding China have seen changes between 2020 and 2021.](image6)

Other major concerns include cyberattacks from China, China's growing technological and military power [8], and political system [image1]. The partisan gap has also grown, with Republicans generally expressing more negative views [3]. For example, 62% of Republicans reported “very cold” feelings, a 31% increase since 2018, while 38% percent of Democrats expressed the same, up 21% over the same time period [3].
![Republicans have much colder feelings toward China when compared to Democrats.](image4)

Nearly half of Americans (48%) believe that limiting China's power and influence should be a top foreign policy priority, an increase of 16 percentage points since 2018 [6].

In summary, American perceptions of China have significantly worsened since 2018, driven by concerns over human rights, economic issues, cyberattacks, and China's growing power.

Americans express substantial concern across several issues in the U.S.-China relationship, with a few key areas standing out [3].

The top concerns, where half or more Americans express that these are *very* serious problems, include cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China's growing military power, and China's human rights policies [3]. These concerns have intensified over time. For example, from 2020 to 2021, there's been a noticeable increase in the percentage of Americans who view these issues as very serious problems:
![Concerns on China](image2)
This image highlights specific concerns like cyberattacks and human rights, and it shows the percentage change between 2020 and 2021.

Furthermore, many Americans are critical of China's handling of key global issues. A significant majority (79%) believe China is doing a bad job dealing with global climate change [6]. Americans also have less faith in President Biden's ability to deal with China compared to other foreign policy issues [4]. Only 53% express confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China, compared to 60% for world affairs in general [11, 12].
![Confidence with China](image6)
The image shows Biden's confidence dealing with China.

When Americans think of China, human rights and the economy are top of mind [7]. Many also associate China with its powerful economy and its role as a manufacturing center, often noting the negative impacts on the environment or workers [10].
![Top of mind](image8)
The image shows a word cloud that summarizes the key themes and issues that come to mind for Americans when they think about China.

Overall, there has been a growing sense of concern about China among Americans, the concerns about several issues increased from 2020 to 2021[8].

In conclusion, Americans' key concerns regarding China center on cyberattacks, job losses, military power, human rights, and economic relations, with most of these concerns growing significantly over the past year.

Latinos are generally optimistic about their economic future, with 81% expecting their family's financial situation to improve in the coming year, a significant increase of 14 percentage points since 2008 [4]. This optimism surpasses that of the general population, among whom 61% share the same view, up by 6 percentage points during the same period [5]. A visual representation of this trend is presented, showing a consistent gap between Hispanic and general public financial expectations.
![Hispanic financial expectations compared to the general public.](image5)

Optimism among Latinos has risen more sharply than in the general population since 2008 [5]. Specifically, the share of Latinos expecting financial improvement increased by 14 percentage points, compared to a 6 percentage point increase for the general population [5].
![Change in percentage of population expecting financial improvement between 2008 and 2015.](image6)

Breaking down the data by subgroups reveals that optimism has increased across most Latino demographics [6]. The changes within specific Latino subgroups are detailed, with significant increases noted among U.S.-born and foreign-born Hispanics, both up by 14 percentage points [3].
![Change in financial outlook from 2008 to 2015 among Latinos by demographics.](image8)

Four-in-ten Latinos report their finances are in "excellent" or "good" shape, a 17 percentage point increase, versus general population remain flat during same period [8].
![Percentage of population with positive financial conditions in 2008 and 2015, with changes noted.](image7)

In summary, financial optimism among Latinos has significantly increased from 2008 to 2015, outpacing the growth in optimism observed in the general population, with notable increases across various demographic subgroups.

Hispanics' financial expectations for their children are influenced by their current financial situations and educational levels. Those with a positive view of their current financial situation are more likely to believe their family's finances will improve [4]. For instance, those in excellent or good financial condition show high optimism that their children will be better off [8].

![Hispanics in excellent or good financial condition express more optimism about their children's financial futures.](image8)

Educational attainment also plays a role in shaping these expectations [10]. Latino high school graduates are more optimistic, with 79% predicting their children will be better off financially, compared to 69% of those with at least some college experience [10].

![Educational attainment impacts Hispanics' expectations for their children's financial futures.](image3)

In summary, current financial standing and educational background significantly influence Hispanics' expectations for their children's financial future, with those in better financial situations and high school graduates being the most optimistic.

Latinos have become more optimistic about their personal finances and future economic prospects since the Great Recession [1]. The percentage of Latinos who expect their finances to improve has significantly increased since 2011 [2].
![Expect their financial situation to improve a lot or some in the coming year](image3)
This image shows the growing optimism among Latinos about their family finances.

However, economic indicators show a mixed picture [6]. While the Latino unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, it remains above its 2006 low and is higher than that for non-Hispanic workers [6, 7].
![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image7)
This image displays the trend of the unemployment rate, with the Latino unemployment rate higher than the non-Hispanic rate.

Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated, and their poverty rate remains above pre-recession levels [5].
![Median Household Income, Median household net worth, percent below poverty line](image2)
The net worth of Hispanic households continued to fall even after the recession, depicting limited progress in community economic indicators.

In summary, while Latinos' perceptions of their financial well-being have become more positive, actual economic indicators, like unemployment trends and income levels, reveal a more complex situation with improvements in some areas but ongoing challenges in others.

The unemployment rate for the Hispanic population has shown improvement since the Great Recession, decreasing from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015, and further to 5.6% in the first quarter of 2016 [8]. However, this rate remains above its pre-recession low of 5% in the fourth quarter of 2006 and is higher than that for non-Hispanic workers [8].
![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image8)

Despite these mixed economic indicators, Hispanics are more optimistic about the national economic conditions compared to other groups [5]. In a December 2015 survey, 35% of Hispanics rated economic conditions as good or excellent, a higher share than among whites (25%) [5]. Additionally, 34% of Hispanics believed that U.S. economic conditions would improve in the coming year, about double the proportion seen among other groups of Americans [5]. The views of Hispanics on their financial situation are also more positive now than they were in 2004 [6].
![General public](image4)

However, there are disparities within the Hispanic community itself. For example, in 2015, Latinos with some college education or who were U.S.-born were more likely to report their personal financial situation as excellent or good [9].
![General
population](image3)

As for income, the median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, standing at $42,491 in 2014 [2].
![All
households](image2)

In terms of wealth, Hispanic households experienced a substantial decline in net worth and it continued to fall after the recession [2].

The trends show that while Hispanics are generally more optimistic about the economy and their financial future, the actual economic indicators such as unemployment rates, income, and wealth reveal a more complex picture with persistent disparities compared to non-Hispanic populations.

From 2000 to 2015, Hispanic households experienced distinct economic challenges compared to all U.S. households across several key indicators.

  In terms of unemployment, the Hispanic rate improved since the Great Recession, decreasing from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015, and further to 5.6% in the first quarter of 2016 [7].
![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image4)
However, it remained above its low of 5% in the fourth quarter of 2006 and higher than that of non-Hispanic workers in the fourth quarter of 2015 [7, 9].

Regarding median household income, Hispanics experienced stagnation since the Great Recession, with a median income of $42,491 in 2014, a level essentially unchanged since that period [8].
![ $60 thousand ........--.---2.--- All households  =O $53,700 Hispanic  ° $42,500 20 wnBheveeecces ee BE oases  )  2000 2014  $150 thousand ........-.-------  $135,700 a i. =O Hispanic se __ 23.6% 100 |  All households  All households $81,400 14.8% 10 %---+------+220+- ete eeeee eee ee BO we--se-e-e eves stati eeeeeeee $23,600 ee Hispanic 0 A (0) $13,700 2000 2014 2001 2013](image5)
The income for all households was also little changed [8].

The Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%, lower than the peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels, mirroring the trend for all Americans [8].

In terms of wealth, Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in their net worth through 2009 among any major racial or ethnic group, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession [8].

In summary, while Hispanic households saw improvements in unemployment rates, their income stagnated, poverty rates remained elevated, and wealth declined significantly compared to all U.S. households from 2000 to 2015.

From 2008 to 2015, perceptions of personal financial situations among Latinos have significantly improved. Four-in-ten Latinos reported their personal finances to be in "excellent" or "good" shape in 2015, marking a 17 percentage point increase from 2008 [10]. This positive shift is observed across most major Latino demographic subgroups [8, 9]. For instance, positive views increased by 17 percentage points among both U.S.-born and foreign-born Hispanics [6]. Similar gains were seen among Latino men (+16 percentage points) and Latina women (+18 percentage points) [6].

![Perceptions of personal finances improved among all Latino subgroups between 2008 and 2015.](image6)

However, the picture is different when considering family income relative to the cost of living. Between 2014 and 2015, Hispanic views on this matter remained unchanged, with about half of all Hispanic adults reporting that they were falling behind financially [4]. In 2015, about 53% of Latinos stated their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living [11].
![Latino families' income in relation to living costs](image1)

In Summary, while Latinos' perceptions of their personal financial situations have improved significantly between 2008 and 2015, their views on family income relative to the cost of living remained largely unchanged, with many feeling they were falling behind.

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors differ notably from the general adult population. While a majority of adults aged 18+ use the internet (86%), only 59% of those aged 65+ do so [3, image7]. Broadband adoption shows a similar trend, with 70% of all adults having it at home compared to 47% of seniors [image7].

Device ownership also varies significantly. A smaller proportion of seniors own cell phones (77%) compared to the general adult population [image5]. The disparity is even more pronounced with smartphones, where only 18% of seniors own one, in stark contrast to the broader adult population [image6].

![Smartphone and Tablet Ownership Among Seniors](image6)

However, among seniors who do use the internet, a significant majority (71%) go online every day or almost every day [7]. This figure is comparable to younger age groups.

![Daily Internet Usage by Age Group](image4)

Additionally, 27% of older adults use social networking sites such as Facebook [9].

![SNS Usage of Older Adults](image1)

Internet Usage of Seniors decreases substantially for seniors in their mid-70s [10].

![Internet and Broadband Usage by Age Group](image8)

In conclusion, while internet usage and device ownership are lower among seniors compared to the general adult population, those seniors who are online tend to use the internet frequently.

Device ownership among older adults has a notable relationship with their internet usage patterns. Although a significant majority of older adults (77%) own a cell phone, these are often basic models rather than smartphones [7]. Smartphone adoption among older adults is relatively low, at just 18% [7], as depicted in the comparison:

![Cell phone Smartphone](image5)

Despite the lower smartphone adoption, a substantial portion of seniors are engaging with other types of devices. Tablet computers and e-book readers are as popular as smartphones among older adults, with 18% owning each [4]. In fact, a larger proportion (27%) of seniors own either a tablet or an e-book reader compared to those owning a smartphone [4], which contrasts with the general population where smartphones are more common [4]:

![Smartphone Tablet or e-reader](image6)

Internet usage among older adults has been steadily increasing. As of the data provided, 59% of seniors report using the internet [6], a trend that has been growing over the years:

![Increase trend of 65+ using Internet.](image4)

Among older adults who use the internet, a significant majority (71%) go online every day or almost every day [5].

![% of internet users in each age group who go online ..](image3)

In summary, while smartphone ownership is low among older adults, their use of other devices like tablets and e-readers is on par with smartphones, and a majority of seniors who are online use the internet daily.

Smartphone ownership among all adults is 55%, while it is only 18% for seniors [1, 5]. Tablet or e-reader ownership is at 43% for all adults, compared to 27% for seniors [1, 7].

![Smartphone and Tablet or e-reader ownership differs between all adults and those over 65.](image1)

Internet usage is notably different between the general adult population and seniors. As of the data provided, 86% of all U.S. adults go online, whereas only 59% of seniors report using the internet [11].

![Internet usage percentage differs between all adults and those over 65.](image4)

Broadband adoption also shows a significant difference. A much smaller percentage of seniors (47%) have broadband at home compared to the general adult population [6, image6]. Over time, internet adoption among seniors has been increasing. In 2000, only a small fraction of seniors used the internet, but by 2012, this number had risen to 59% [11]. Although this is a substantial increase, it still trails the overall adult population's adoption rate [11].
Cell phone ownership is high among seniors (77%), it is still lower than that of all adults (91%) [image3, 5].

![Cell phone ownership percentages are different between all adults and those 65 and older.](image3)

Additionally, 27% of older adults use social networking sites [4].

![27% of seniors use social media, compared to 41% who do not use the internet at all.](image2)

In summary, seniors have lower rates of device ownership (especially smartphones) and internet usage compared to the general adult population, although internet adoption among seniors has shown significant growth over time.

Device ownership and online social networking habits among seniors show distinct trends. Although a significant majority of seniors, 59%, report using the internet [8], and the adoption rates are increasing [2], only a quarter of them actively use online social networks [9]. A visual breakdown shows that 27% of older adults use social networking sites (SNS) like Facebook [4], while 32% go online but do not use SNS, and 41% do not go online at all.
![Use SNS](image4)
Interestingly, among the general adult population, smartphones are more prevalent than tablets or e-readers, but this trend is not mirrored among older adults [7]. Seniors are just as likely to own a tablet or an e-book reader as they are a smartphone [7], with 18% owning each [7].
![mSmartphone «Tablet or e-reader](image3)
Moreover, seniors with physical or health conditions that make reading difficult, or have a disability that impacts daily activities, show a relatively higher adoption rate of tablets and e-readers, at 29% and 23% respectively [5].
![BAll adults m65+](image1)

In summary, while a notable percentage of seniors are online, their social networking engagement is limited compared to their adoption of devices like tablets and e-readers, which are as popular as smartphones among this demographic.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors show significant variation based on age, education, and income [5, 7].

As depicted in the data, internet usage and broadband adoption decrease significantly around age 75 [3, 5]. Specifically, $59\%$ of seniors aged 65 and older use the internet, and $47\%$ have broadband at home. When broken down further, $74\%$ of those aged 65-69 use the internet, compared to just $37\%$ of those 80 and older. Similarly, broadband adoption is at $65\%$ for the 65-69 age group and drops to $21\%$ for those 80 and older.
![Internet and broadband adoption rates differ significantly by age group within the senior population.](image6)

Education level also plays a crucial role. Among seniors with a high school education or less, $40\%$ use the internet, and $27\%$ have broadband. These figures increase significantly for college graduates, with $87\%$ using the internet and $76\%$ having broadband [2, 8].
![Internet and broadband adoption rates show variation across education levels.](image6)

Income is another major factor. For seniors with an annual household income of less than $30,000, internet usage is at $39\%$, and broadband adoption is at $25\%$. In contrast, for those with an income of $75,000 or more, $90\%$ use the internet, and $82\%$ have broadband [2, 8].
![Internet and broadband adoption rates show variation across income levels.](image6)

Overall, while $86\%$ of all U.S. adults use the internet, only $59\%$ of seniors do [1].
![Internet usage among seniors is increasing, but still lags behind the general population.](image5)

In summary, internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults are significantly lower than the general population and vary considerably based on age, education, and income, with younger, more educated, and higher-income seniors having much higher adoption rates.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors show significant variation based on income and education. Seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more exhibit high rates: 90% go online and 82% have broadband at home [8]. In contrast, among seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, only 39% go online and 25% have broadband at home [8].
![Broadband and internet usage based on the annual income of seniors.](image3)
Education levels also play a crucial role. Fully 87% of seniors with a college degree go online, and 76% are broadband adopters [6, 8]. However, among seniors who have not attended college, only 40% go online, and just 27% have broadband at home [8].
![Cell phone and smartphone usage by education level of seniors.](image8)
Similarly, cell phone and smartphone adoption rates vary by income and education. For instance, 92% of seniors with an income of $75,000 or more own a cell phone, and 42% own a smartphone [8]. Among those with less than $30,000 income, 67% are cell phone owners and 8% have smartphones [8]. Regarding education, 87% of seniors with college degree have Cell phone and 35% own a smartphone, while 70% those with a high school degree or less own cell phone, and just 10% have smartphones [8].

In summary, internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates among seniors are significantly higher for those with higher income and education levels.

Technology adoption rates among older adults (65+) show significant variations based on income and education levels, especially when compared to the general population.

Specifically, internet usage and broadband adoption are notably higher among affluent and well-educated seniors [1]. For instance, 90% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more go online, and 82% have broadband at home. ![Broadband at home](image1) In contrast, only 39% of seniors with an income less than $30,000 go online, and just 25% have broadband [1], ![Broadband at home](image1).

Education also plays a crucial role. 87% of seniors who are college graduates use the internet, and 76% have broadband. ![Broadband at home](image1) These figures are much lower for those with a high school education or less, where only 40% go online and 27% have broadband [1], ![Broadband at home](image1).

Smartphone ownership follows a similar pattern. While 77% of all seniors own cell phones, only 18% own smartphones [7, 8]. ![Cell phone Smartphone](image4) However, among seniors earning $75,000 or more, smartphone ownership rises to 42%, and among college-graduate seniors, it is 35%[9]. ![Cell phone Smartphone](image4) These rates are still lower than the national average; where 91% of all American adults own a cell phone, and 55% own a smartphone. The adoption of tablet computers and e-readers also shows the influence of wealth on the use of technology by older adults [4]. ![mSmartphone «Tablet or e-reader](image5)

In summary, internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults are significantly influenced by income and education, with higher rates among wealthier and more educated seniors, though these rates still lag behind the overall population trends.

Internet usage among seniors varies significantly based on educational attainment. College graduates show the highest rates of internet usage, with 87% going online [1]. Seniors with some college education follow, with 69% using the internet [1]. In contrast, seniors who are high school graduates or less have a significantly lower internet usage rate of 40% [1].

![Internet usage and broadband adoption vary greatly among seniors based on education level.](image1)

Smartphone ownership also differs substantially by education level within the senior population. College graduates have the highest smartphone ownership at 35% [8]. Those with some college education have a lower rate of 19%, and seniors with a high school education or less have only a 10% smartphone ownership rate [8].
![Smartphone adoption rates differ among seniors based on their level of education.](image8)

In conclusion, internet usage and smartphone ownership are significantly higher among seniors with higher educational attainment compared to those with less education.

Internet and broadband adoption rates, along with cell phone and smartphone ownership, vary significantly among seniors based on education and income levels.

Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online and 82% have broadband at home [12]. Seniors in this income bracket are also more likely to own cell phones and smartphones. Specifically, 92% own cell phones and 42% own smartphones.
![Cell phone Smartphone](image5)

In contrast, among seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, only 39% go online, and 25% have broadband at home [12]. Cell phone ownership is at 67%, while smartphone ownership is significantly lower, at just 8%.
![Cell phone Smartphone](image5)

When considering education, 87% of seniors with a college degree go online, and 76% are broadband adopters [12]. Additionally, 87% of college-educated seniors own cell phones, and 35% own smartphones.
![Cell phone Smartphone](image5)

For seniors who have not attended college, 40% go online, and only 27% have broadband at home [12]. Among this group, 70% own cell phones, but only 10% own smartphones.
![Cell phone Smartphone](image5)
These figures indicate substantial differences in the way seniors in 65+ adopt different technologies.

![Total for all 65+
Age](image2)

In summary, internet and broadband adoption, as well as cell phone and smartphone ownership, are much higher among seniors with higher education and income levels compared to those with lower education and income levels.

Broadband adoption rates among seniors vary significantly based on educational attainment and household income.

Among seniors with an annual household income of \$75,000 or more, 82% have broadband at home [9]. This contrasts sharply with seniors earning less than \$30,000 annually, where only 25% have broadband at home [9].

Similarly, educational attainment plays a significant role. 76% of seniors with a college degree are broadband adopters [9]. However, among seniors who have not attended college, only 27% have broadband at home [9].

These disparities are also reflected in a detailed breakdown:
![Broadband adoption varies significantly among seniors based on income and education levels.](image5)

In summary, broadband adoption at home is much higher among seniors with higher income and education levels.

Tablet and e-book reader adoption among seniors is significantly influenced by their education level. College graduates aged 65 and older are much more likely to own these devices compared to those with lower educational attainment [12]. Specifically, 30% of seniors with a college degree own an e-book reader, and 44% own a tablet computer [8]. In contrast, only 12% of seniors with a high school education or less own an e-book reader, and just 9% own a tablet [8].
![Tablet and e-book reader ownership significantly vary by education level among seniors.](image8)

This trend mirrors the broader national pattern where tablet and e-book reader adoption is most prevalent among college graduates and higher-income Americans [12].

Over time, technology adoption, in general, has been increasing across all age groups, but older adults, including seniors, consistently lag behind younger demographics. This trend is observable from 2000 to 2012, showing a growing proportion of adults and seniors who have ever used the internet.
![The percentage of Internet usage is lower for individuals aged 65 and older compared to the general adult population.](image5)

The usage of social networking sites by older Americans has been steadily increasing in recent years [9].

In conclusion, education level significantly impacts the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors, with higher adoption rates among college graduates, which aligns with general national trends, although seniors generally adopt technology at lower rates than younger age groups.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have more positive views of many workplace technologies [10]. This is evident in how different educational groups perceive the impact of technology on their careers. For instance, college graduates are substantially more likely than those with high school diplomas or less to say that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [2].

![Made their work more interesting Increased their opportunities for advancement](image7)

Specific technologies, such as word processing or spreadsheet software, show pronounced differences: 90% of college graduates feel these technologies have had a positive impact, compared to only 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [12]. Similar trends are observed with other technologies, including email, social media, smartphones, and scheduling software [12].

![Word processing or spreadsheet software Smartphones Email or social media Software that manages daily schedules Customer self-service technologies Industrial robots](image3)

In contrast, a significant portion of workers with high school diplomas or less (24%) feel that none of the six technologies measured have positively impacted their jobs or careers, whereas only 2% of college graduates feel the same [12].

As for the future of the development and adoption of automation technologies [6], many Americans anticipate significant advancements in technologies like driverless vehicles [8]. The vast majority (94%) are aware of efforts to develop driverless vehicles, and about two-thirds expect that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next 50 years [8].

![56](image1)

Educational attainment significantly influences perceptions of workforce technologies, with higher education correlating with more positive views, and a majority of Americans expect driverless cars to become widespread within 50 years.

Workers with varying levels of educational attainment express pronounced differences in their views of workplace technology [8]. Those with at least a four-year college degree have markedly more positive views compared with those with high school diplomas or less [9].

For instance, there is a 45-percentage-point difference in the share of workers with college degrees (90%) and with high school diplomas or less (45%) who feel that office productivity tools such as word processing or spreadsheet software have had a positive impact on them professionally [9]. This trend is visible across various technologies:

![Different technologies have varying impacts on people's careers.](image5)

In general, roughly half of all workers (53%) feel that technology has made their work more interesting, while 46% believe it has increased their opportunities for career advancement.

![Technology makes work more interesting for some, while increasing advancement opportunities for others.](image1)

Many Americans anticipate significant advancements in automation technologies, with driverless vehicles being a prominent example [1]. A significant majority (about two-thirds) of the public anticipates that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century, with 9% predicting this will occur in the next 10 years [1].

![A majority of people expect that in 10 to 50 years, most cars will be driverless.](image4)

In conclusion, higher education levels correlate with more positive perceptions of workforce technologies, and there is a broad expectation that driverless cars will become widespread within the next 50 years.

Many Americans foresee significant changes due to automation technologies, with driverless vehicles being a prime example [1]. A large majority (94%) are aware of the efforts to develop such vehicles, and about two-thirds expect them to dominate the roads within 50 years, with 9% anticipating this within the next decade [1]. The distribution of when people believe driverless cars will be majority is shown, with the biggest portion of respondents feeling like it will be 10 to 50 years before this change occurs.
![The distribution of when people believe driverless cars will be majority is shown, with the biggest portion of respondents feeling like it will be 10 to 50 years before this change occurs.](image8)

However, current workforce technologies have had diverse impacts on today's workers [6]. While some, particularly those with higher education, view technology positively, enhancing their work and career prospects, those without college education are less likely to see such benefits [6]. The image shows a mixed view, as 53% agree that tech made their work more interesting, while 34% stated tech had no impact either way.
![53% agree that tech made their work more interesting, while 34% stated tech had no impact either way.](image3)
A variety of technologies have impact workers, with the positive, negative, and indifferent reactions to these technologies depicted.
![A variety of technologies have impact workers, with the positive, negative, and indifferent reactions to these technologies depicted.](image4)

Many workers feel that technology generally makes their work more interesting (53%) and increases opportunities for career advancement (46%) [12]. However, many also stated that technology has had no effect [12].

In summary, while Americans anticipate significant future impacts from automation like driverless vehicles, the current experiences of workers with technology are mixed, with benefits often tied to educational attainment and specific types of technology used.

Workers' views on the impact of workplace technologies vary significantly based on their educational attainment [10]. College graduates are notably more positive about these technologies compared to those with a high school diploma or less [1].

A significant difference is observed in the perception of office productivity tools, such as word processing or spreadsheet software. A substantial 90% of workers with college degrees believe these technologies have positively impacted them professionally, compared to only 45% of those with high school diplomas or less [1]. This disparity also extends to other technologies, including email, social media, smartphones, and scheduling software [1].
![Workplace Technology Impact by Education Level](image4)

In terms of overall impact, only 38% of workers with a high school education or less find that technology has made their jobs more interesting, and 32% feel it has increased their career advancement opportunities [2]. These figures are considerably lower than those reported by workers with higher education levels [2]. The data shows that 64% of college graduates say technology made their work more interesting, while 53% reported increased opportunities.
![Impact of Workplace Technologies on Career Interest and Opportunities](image1)
Many non-college educated workers report that technologies have not significantly impacted their careers. For example, 44% of workers with a high school diploma or less state that word processing or spreadsheet software have had no impact, and 35% say the same about email or social media [7].

In conclusion, perceptions of workplace technologies differ significantly by education level, with college graduates generally having a more positive view of their impact on job interest and career opportunities compared to those with a high school diploma or less.

Workers with higher levels of education are more likely to say technology has increased opportunities and made their jobs more interesting [2]. The survey data indicates a correlation between educational attainment and the perceived positive impact of workplace technologies [5]. Specifically, college graduates are substantially more likely than those with a high school diploma or less to report that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [12].
![Made their work more interesting, increased their opportunities for advancement](image1)
These differences are most pronounced with office productivity tools like word processing or spreadsheet software, with a 45-percentage point difference between college graduates (90%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45%) who feel these technologies have had a positive impact [11]. There are differences of 20 percentage points or more between these groups for other technologies like email, social media, smartphones and software of managing workers' daily schedules and routines [11].
![A positive, a negative or no impact either way](image6)
A significant portion (24%) of workers with high school diplomas or less say that none of the six technologies inquired about had a positive impact on their jobs, compared to just 2% of college graduates [6, 11].

In conclusion, educational attainment significantly influences the perceived impact of technologies on work, with higher education levels correlating with a more positive perception of technology's role in making work more interesting and enhancing career advancement opportunities.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have more positive views of workplace technologies [8, 9]. College graduates are substantially more likely to say that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement (53%) compared to workers with high school diplomas or less (32%) [10].  ![College graduates more often find technology increases job opportunities.](image1)

Similarly, a larger percentage of college graduates (64%) believe technology has made their work more interesting, in contrast to high school graduates or less (38%) [10]. These differences are most pronounced in the use of office productivity tools, with 90% of college-educated workers reporting a positive impact, compared to only 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [1]. A significant portion of workers with high school diplomas or less (44%) feel that word processing or spreadsheet software has not impacted their professional lives, while 35% say the same about email or social media [2].

Moreover, individuals with high school diplomas or less are more downbeat about the impact of these tools on their careers compared to college graduates [5].  Workers in the middle educational tier—those who have graduated from high school but lack four-year college degrees—tend to have attitudes toward technology and work that are midway between these two groups, They express more positive views relative to those with no college experience at all, but less positive views relative to those with four-year degrees or more [12].

In summary, educational attainment significantly influences perceptions of technology in the workplace, with higher education levels correlating with more positive views on technology's impact on job opportunities and work interest.

Americans who have heard a lot about the concept of machines taking over many human jobs show greater enthusiasm for the idea, but also express substantial concerns, mirroring those with less awareness [6, 11]. Specifically, 47% of those who have heard a lot about this concept express some level of enthusiasm, a figure significantly higher than those with lower familiarity [10].
![Americans who had heard varying amounts about the concept of automation show corresponding levels of enthusiasm and worry.](image1)
However, worry remains consistently high across all awareness levels. 76% of those who have heard a lot about this concept express some level of worry, comparable to 72% of those who have heard a little and 69% of those who have heard nothing [5].

Americans generally anticipate more negative than positive outcomes from a world where machines perform many jobs currently done by humans [7]. A significant majority (76%) expect increased economic inequality, and 64% believe people will struggle to find meaningful activities [4, 9].
![Most people, regardless of political affiliation, think inequality will worsen; a minority think new, better-paying jobs will be created.](image6)
Only 25% expect the creation of many new, well-paying jobs [12].

In summary, greater awareness of automation leads to increased enthusiasm but does not reduce worry among Americans, who predominantly expect negative outcomes such as increased inequality and job displacement.

Public opinion on policies regarding workforce automation differs significantly between Democrats and Republicans, particularly when it comes to government intervention. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more supportive of a guaranteed income and a national service program if machines displace many human workers [7, 12]. Specifically, 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income, compared to 38% of Republicans, and 66% of Democrats support a national service program, versus 46% of Republicans [12].
![Democrats are more supportive of guaranteed income and national service programs](image6)

However, there's more alignment on limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines [2]. A slight majority of Republicans (54%) believe there should be limits, which is not far from the 60% of Democrats who hold this view [2].
![Support for limiting machines is aligned between parties.](image8)

Regardless of political affiliation, the vast majority of Americans support limiting machines to performing dangerous and unhealthy jobs [1].
![Most people oppose limiting machines to dangerous jobs.](image1)
Overall, 85% of Americans favor this policy [3].

In summary, while Democrats are more likely to support government programs like universal basic income and national service in response to job displacement by automation, both Democrats and Republicans generally agree on limiting machines to dangerous jobs and restricting the replacement of human workers by machines.

There are notable partisan divisions regarding the government's obligation to assist workers displaced by machines. Democrats and those leaning Democratic are more supportive of the government taking care of displaced workers, even if it necessitates higher taxes (65%) [4]. Conversely, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even amidst widespread job automation (68%) [4]. This division is visually represented, showing how different groups perceive the government's role versus individual responsibility.

Educational differences also impact views, particularly on whether businesses should be limited in automating jobs [10]. A larger percentage of individuals with a high school diploma or less (70%) believe there should be limits on job replacement by machines, compared to college graduates (41%) [6]. Democrats more supportive of guaranteed income, national service program in the event of widespread job losses due to automation [8].

However, partisan opinions are more aligned on limiting the number of human jobs businesses can replace with machines, with slight differences between Republicans (54%) and Democrats (60%) [2].

In summary, political affiliation significantly influences views on government responsibility for displaced workers, while education level affects opinions on limiting job automation by businesses.

Political affiliation significantly shapes American views on policies concerning workforce automation and job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are notably more supportive of a universal basic income, with 77% in favor compared to just 38% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [4]. Democrats are more supportive of guaranteed income and national service program in the event of widespread job losses due to automation [7]. A similar divide exists for a national service program, favored by 66% of Democrats versus 46% of Republicans [4, 9].
![Democrats are more supportive than Republicans of a guaranteed income and a national service program.](image6)

However, there's more alignment on other related policies. The vast majority of Americans, irrespective of party affiliation, support limiting machines to performing dangerous and dirty jobs [9].
![Support and Opposition for Automation Policies](image7)
Additionally, comparable shares of Democrats (60%) and Republicans (54%) believe there should be general limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with robots or computers [4, 11].

When considering the government's obligation to care for workers displaced by automation, 65% of Democrats believe the government should be responsible, even if it means higher taxes, a view opposed by 68% of Republicans who believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [3].
![The obligation of government and individuals for providing for displaced workers.](image1)

In summary, Democrats are more likely to support government interventions like universal basic income and national service programs in response to job displacement, while Republicans generally favor individual responsibility, although both parties find common ground in limiting automation to dangerous jobs and setting some restrictions on job replacement by machines.

A minority of Americans have already been impacted by these technologies in their own jobs and careers [3]. Attitudes toward workforce automation and the perceived impact of technology vary significantly across different age groups and educational levels, revealing a spectrum of experiences and sentiments.

Younger adults, particularly those aged 18 to 24, are among the groups most likely to have been personally impacted by workforce automation [3, image4].

Workers with higher levels of education generally have more positive views of many workplace technologies [4]. College graduates are substantially more likely than workers with high school diplomas or less to say that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [2, 5].
![Made their work more interesting Increased their opportunities for advancement](image5)
In contrast, workers without a college education express less positive attitudes toward the current generation of workforce technologies [10]. Only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less indicate that technology has made their jobs more interesting, and 32% feel it has increased their career advancement opportunities [12].

Workers who have been impacted by automation express strongly negative views about the current and future impact of technology on their careers [1]. 46% of these workers feel that technology has decreased their opportunities for career advancement, while 34% feel that technology has generally made their work less interesting [1].
![A negative A positive
impact impact](image3)
In summary, attitudes towards workforce automation and technology's impact vary significantly, with younger workers and those with less education reporting more negative experiences and perceptions, while those with higher education levels tend to view technology more positively.

Workers' views on the impact of technology in the workplace vary significantly based on educational attainment and other demographic factors. College graduates are substantially more likely than those who have not attended college to say that various workforce technologies have had a positive impact on their jobs or careers [6].

A significant portion of workers with high school diplomas or less,  indicate that technology in general has made their jobs more interesting (38%) [10]. A similar percentage (32%) feel that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement [10]. These figures are much lower than those reported by workers with more formal education beyond high school [10].
![Made their work more interesting; Increased their opportunities for advancement](image1)

Compared with workers with high school diplomas or less, college graduates are substantially more likely to say that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [9].
The benefits of workforce technologies largely accrue to workers with high levels of formal educational attainment [2, 1]. Technology represents a mostly positive force for some, especially those with high levels of educational attainment, making their work more interesting and providing career advancement opportunities [1]. Those who have not attended college are less likely to view workforce technologies in a positive light [1, 11].

In conclusion, perceptions of the impact of workforce automation and technology vary significantly, with higher-educated workers generally reporting more positive experiences and benefits compared to those with less education.

Workers with higher levels of education are more likely to say technology has increased opportunities and made their jobs more interesting [6]. College graduates are substantially more likely than workers with high school diplomas or less to state that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [5].
![Workers with college degrees are more likely to say technology has made their jobs more interesting and increased opportunities.](image5)
In contrast, only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less think that technology has made their jobs more interesting, and 32% believe it has increased their career advancement opportunities [11].

A substantial share of workers indicate that technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email or social media (60%) have had a positive impact on their own careers [10].
![Specific technologies cited as having a positive impact on workers' careers.](image6)
However, around one-third (34%) say technology hasn’t had a major impact either way on the interestingness of their job [3].
![The percentage of the workers think technology made their work more interesting.](image1)

In conclusion, education levels significantly influence workers' perceptions of technology's impact, with college-educated workers viewing technology more positively in terms of job interest and career advancement compared to those with less education.

Younger adults (18-29) are twice as likely to report feeling amused (54%) as they are to feel angry (27%) [6]. However, older users (65 and older) experience these emotions with comparable frequency (30% amused and 24% angry) [6, 7]. Notably, younger adults are more prone to feeling lonely (15%) compared to older adults (4% for those 50 and older) [7]. A larger share of the young social media users also mentioned that these platforms frequently make them feel amused but also lonely and depressed [8].

The data regarding frequently experience content on social media that make them feel for different age groups are also visualized in a bar chart [8], different age groups are categorized into:
*   Ages 65+
*   Ages 50-64
*   Ages 30-49
*   Ages 18-29

The emotions listed are Amused, Angry, Connected, Inspired, Depressed and Lonely.

Across all age groups, amusement is the most commonly experienced emotion, with 88% of users reporting they see content that makes them feel amused [5]. 44% experience this emotion frequently [5, 7]. Other frequently experienced emotions are:
*   Angry (71% sometimes and 25% frequently)
*   Connected (71% sometimes and 21% frequently)
*  Inspired (69% sometimes and 17% frequently)
*  Depressed (49% sometimes and 11% frequently)

The most frequently experienced emotion on social media across all users is amusement.

Younger adults, aged 18-29, are more likely to report feeling amused (54%) than angry (27%) on social media [4]. However, they are also more likely to report feeling lonely (15%) compared to older adults aged 30-49 (7%) and those 50 and older (4%) [6].
![Feelings of amused, angry, connected, inspired, depressed and lonely on social media.](image5)
In contrast, users aged 65 and older experience amusement (30%) and anger (24%) with more comparable frequency [6]. A smaller share of older adults are frequently amused by the content they encounter on social media [6].

Regarding content exposure, a significant portion of users across all age groups frequently see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts (59%) [12].
![Posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated versus people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts](image1)

Different age groups on social media experience a range of emotions, with younger users reporting higher rates of amusement but also loneliness, while older users experience amusement and anger more equally, and users of all ages often encounter dramatic or argumentative content.

Younger adults are more likely to experience feelings of loneliness on social media compared to older adults [7]. Specifically, 15% of social media users aged 18 to 29 report frequently feeling lonely, while only 7% of those aged 30 to 49 and 4% of those 50 and older say the same [7]. Conversely, older adults are less likely to be frequently amused by content they see on social media [7]. The percentage of users aged 65 and older who frequently feel amused is 30%, which is similar to the 24% who frequently feel angry [7].

![Ages 65+ 50-64 30-49 18-29](image3)

Different emotions show varied experiences across age groups [7]. Identical shares across age groups frequently encounter content that makes them angry [7].

![Frequently Sometimes](image7)

Regarding behaviors, men are about twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [9]. However, majorities of both men (58%) and women (67%) see an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [9]. A slightly larger share of men (29%) than women (19%) say they more often see people being mean or bullying on social media platforms [12].

![People being](image6)

The most common types of content users frequently encounter are posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58% of users see this frequently) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59% see this frequently) [10].

![Frequently Sometimes](image5)

In summary, younger adults report higher rates of loneliness on social media, while older adults are less likely to be amused; men are more likely to observe deceptive and bullying behaviors, and the most common content includes dramatic posts and accusations without facts.

Different age groups experience a range of emotions on social media. Younger users (18-29) report feeling amused more frequently (54%) than older users (65+) (30%). However, they also experience higher levels of depression (24%) and loneliness (25%) compared to older users [4, 8]. Across all age groups, anger is a commonly felt emotion, with 27% of those 18-29 years and 23% of users of Age 65+ feeling it frequently [8].
![Amused](image4)

In terms of behaviors, a majority of users (54%) report seeing an equal mix of kind/supportive and mean/bullying behavior [3, 7]. Men are slightly more likely (29%) than women (19%) to say they more often see mean or bullying behavior [9].
![People being

The most common types of posts encountered frequently across all age groups include those that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%) [8].
