The conditions for Restricted Share Units (RSUs) vesting over the first three years are detailed in the provided documents.

The general vesting schedule for RSUs can occur in full on or before the 30th day of the third month after the end of the third full year, provided the employee remains continuously employed [8].
![NO. OF Restricted share Units Vesting at Vesting Date](image8)
The number of RSUs vesting at each date is determined by adjusting the Annual Target Amount by the Performance Factor for the respective year [11, image8].
For the first full year, the Business Unit's Non-GAAP OI should be no more than 15% less than the Non-GAAP OI objective set in the AOP for that year [image8]. The second and third full years have the same conditions of the relevant year.
Activision Blizzard, may adjust the performance objective [12].

One-third of the 2019 Performance Share Units vest on July 31, 2020, if the 2019 non-GAAP operating income is at least 90% of the 2019 AOP OI Objective [2]. If this condition is met, the number of shares received is the product of the number of First Tranche 2019 Performance Share Units and the ratio of the 2019 OI to the 2019 AOP OI Objective, up to a maximum of 125% [2].

In summary, the vesting conditions include continued employment, and the number of shares that vest can vary based on company performance relative to pre-defined objectives.

To calculate the Days Payable Outstanding (DPO) for Amazon in FY2017, we need to use the following formula:

DPO = (Accounts Payable / Cost of Goods Sold) * Number of Days in the Period

Based on the provided information:

*   **Accounts Payable (2017):** \$34,616 million.
    ![Accounts Payable for 2017 was $34,616 million](image1)

*   **Cost of Goods Sold (2017):** \$111,934 million. This is labeled "Cost of sales".
    ![Cost of Sales is $111,934 million](image5)

*    **Number of Days:** The period is one fiscal year that ended December 31, so 365 days.

Now, plug these values into the formula:

DPO = (34,616 / 111,934) * 365

DPO = 0.30925 * 365

DPO=112.88

Amazon's FY2017 days payable outstanding (DPO) is 112.88.

HDFC Bank engages in related party transactions, notably with its promoter, Housing Development Finance Corporation Limited. A significant transaction involves the purchase of home loans [7]. The bank sources loans and sells HDFC home loans and has the option to purchase up to 70% of the fully-disbursed loans [3].
![Details of home loan transactions between HDFC Bank and Housing Development Finance Corporation Limited.](image7)
In the year under review, HDFC Bank originated, on average, ₹2,470 crore of home loans every month and purchased ₹18,980 crore as a direct assignment of loans [3].

HDFC Bank has two main subsidiaries: HDB Financial Services Limited (HDBFSL) and HDFC Securities Limited (HSL) [9, 12].
![Financial performance of HDFC Bank and its subsidiaries.](image8)
HDB Financial Services Limited (HDBFSL) is a non-banking finance company [12]. HDBFSL’s net interest income grew 6.8 percent to ₹ 4,262.7 crore for the year ended March 31, 2021. Its profit for the year was ₹ 502.8 crore, and its Assets Under Management stood at ₹61,560.7 crore [8]. HDFC Securities Limited (HSL) is a financial services provider with broking as a core product [12]. These subsidiaries contribute to the Bank's strategy by offering services beyond traditional banking [6].

In summary, HDFC Bank's related party transactions primarily involve home loan purchases from its promoter, and its subsidiaries, HDBFSL and HSL, show varied financial performance with HDBFSL contributing significantly to the non-banking financial sector.

Here's an analysis of the provided data to determine the percentage difference in employment rates within respective fields for men and women with STEM degrees:

The question asks the percentage difference of the sum, and the given source only offer several specific majors, so we will calculate every major mentioned in the graph and text.

*   **Computer Degree:** 58% of women, and 53% of men.

*   **Engineering Degree:** 24% of women and 30% of men.

*    **Math Degree:** 44% of women, 47% of men.

*   **Life science Degree:** 33% of women and 30% of men [1].

*    **Physical Science Degree**:29% of women, and 41% of men.

So, (69%+58%+24%+44%+33%+29%)-(61%+53%+30%+47%+30%+41%)=257%-262%=-5%.

Women in STEM jobs face a more challenging workplace environment compared to their male counterparts [4]. A significant 50% of women in STEM report experiencing gender-related discrimination at work, far exceeding the 19% of men in STEM who report the same [5, 10].

![They have ever experienced gender-related discrimination at work](image5)

The types of discrimination commonly reported by women in STEM include earning less than men for the same job (29%), being treated as incompetent (29%), experiencing repeated, small slights (20%), and receiving less support from senior leaders (18%) [2, 8].

![Among women in STEM jobs in workplaces with ...](image3)

These experiences are particularly pronounced for women in majority-male workplaces [12], those in computer jobs [6], and women holding postgraduate degrees [7]. For instance, 78% of women in majority-male STEM workplaces report experiencing gender discrimination [9, 3]. Women in computer jobs are more likely to report discrimination (74%) and pay inequities (46%) than all women in STEM (50% and 29% respectively) [6].

In conclusion, gender discrimination is significantly more prevalent for women in STEM jobs than for men.

In the 2016 election, a unique trend emerged in how voters graded the candidates' conduct. Unlike past elections, the losing candidate, Hillary Clinton, received higher grades than the winning candidate, Donald Trump [11]. About 43% of voters gave Clinton an A or B grade, while only 30% of voters gave Trump an A or B [3, 9, 11]. This is visually represented, which displays the grades given to each candidate from 1988 to 2016, and it is easy to see that Trump is lower than Clinton [image4].

![Grades for the way winning Presidential candidate conducted themselves in the campaign](image4)

Furthermore, Clinton's grades were comparable to those of Mitt Romney in 2012 (44%) [11]. The grades reflect a significant shift, as it was the first time in Pew Research Center post-election surveys that voters gave the losing candidate higher grades than the winner [11].

![Grades for the way losing Presidential candidate conducted themselves in the campaign](image7)

In summary, the public graded Hillary Clinton's conduct during the 2016 presidential campaign higher than that of Donald Trump, marking a departure from previous election trends.

There's a significant partisan divide in the support for requiring government-issued photo identification to vote [8]. Republicans overwhelmingly support this policy (93%) [2, image 3], with a substantial majority (81%) strongly favoring it [11]. Democrats are much less likely to strongly favor photo ID requirements (30%) [11], even as majorities in both groups favor this policy [11].

While a majority of Democrats support requiring photo ID, there are differences within the party based on race and ethnicity. Larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) support the policy compared to White Democrats (54%) [9].
![Democrats are less likely than Republicans to strongly favor photo ID requirements for voting.](image3)

In conclusion, Republicans are much more likely than Democrats to strongly support requiring voters to show photo ID, although majorities in both parties favor this policy.

Between 2003 and 2007, the rezonings across New York City led to varying changes in residential capacity across the boroughs. Queens and Manhattan accounted for three-quarters of the City's net gain in residential capacity [4]. Specifically, residential capacity in Queens and Manhattan increased by 2.8% and 2.3% respectively [7]. Staten Island and Brooklyn saw more modest net increases, 1.4% and 1.2% gains, respectively, and the residential capacity in the Bronx was static [7].
![Figure C: Change in Residential Capacity / 4](image1)

The borough with the highest percentage change was Queens, with a 2.8% increase [7].

Staten Island had a residential development capacity of 435,000,000 square feet in 2003 [3]. Between 2003 and 2007, Staten Island saw a modest net increase of 1.4% in residential capacity [3]. The change in residential capacity, by square feet, as of 2007, was 5,980,000 [3].
![Table A: Residential Development Capacity and the Impact of Rezonings, by Borough (2003-2007)](image3)

The residential capacity of Staten Island from 2003 to 2007 is 435,000,000.

The percentage of Latinos who say all or most of their friends are Latinos varies across generations.

Most immigrant Latinos (77%) report that all or most of their friends are also Latino [11].
![All/Most Some/Only a few](image2)
Among second-generation self-identified Latinos, this share drops to 55% [11].
For third or higher generation self-identified Latinos, the share decreases further to 37% [11].

To calculate the average percentage, we add the percentages for each generation and divide by the number of generations (3):

(77% + 55% + 37%) / 3 = 56.33%

The averaged percentage of Latinos (Foreign born, Second generation, Third or higher generation) who say all or most of their friends are Latinos is approximately 56.33%.

Bengaluru, India, hosts a significant number of facilities that are integral to the Indian Space Programme. These include:

*   **DOS Secretariat and ISRO Headquarters**: Located at Antariksh Bhavan, these offices coordinate major programs such as satellite communication, navigation, earth observation, and launch vehicle programs [3].
*    **ISRO Satellite Centre (ISAC)**: This is ISRO's lead center for the design, development, fabrication, and testing of all Indian-made satellites [5].
*   **ISRO Telemetry, Tracking and Command Network (ISTRAC)**: ISTRAC in Bengaluru has the major responsibility to provide tracking support for all the satellite and launch vehicle missions of ISRO [11]. It also handles mission operations for operational remote sensing and scientific satellites [11].
* **Space Commission**: Is also present in Bengaluru [2].
* **Department of Space**: The organizational chart shows the presence of the Department of Space [2].

![Organisation](image1)

Additionally, the organizational structure places Antrix Corporation, NNRMS Secretariat, and several other offices within Bengaluru [4].
![image4](image4)

In summary, Bengaluru hosts ISRO Headquarters, DOS Secretariat, ISAC, ISTRAC, and Space Commision and other centers, making it a central hub for the Indian Space Programme.

Americans express substantial concern regarding several issues in the U.S.-China relationship [5]. However, four problems stand out as "very serious" for at least half of those surveyed [5]:

*   **Cyberattacks from China:** This concern has seen a notable increase between 2020 and 2021. ![Cyberattacks from China](image7)
*   **China's policies on human rights:** Half of Americans now consider this a very serious problem, marking a 7-percentage-point increase since last year [12]. One-in-five Americans mention human rights concerns when asked about China [11], and some specifically mention the Uyghurs in Xinjiang [11].
*    **Economic**: It includes loss of US jobs to China [5], and China's economic power [3]. The concerns on "Made in China", manufacturing, bad products and knockoffs are also frequently cited [4]. ![Economy](image4)
*   **China's growing military power:** This is another key area of concern [5].

In an open-ended question about what comes to mind when thinking about China, human rights and the economy are top of mind for many Americans [10]. ![Human rights](image4)

The top concerns Americans have about China, based on the survey data, are cyberattacks, human rights policies, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, and China's growing military power.

There are notable differences in views on making Election Day a national holiday across racial groups [11]. White adults are less likely to favor making Election Day a national holiday compared to Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults [11]. Specifically, a majority of Black (86%), Hispanic (75%), and Asian (79%) adults favor making Election Day a National Holiday, while a smaller proportion of White adults (57%) support this policy.

![A majority of Black (86%), Hispanic (75%), and Asian (79%) adults favor making Election Day a National Holiday, while a smaller proportion of White adults (57%) support this policy.](image4)

This is further supported by data showing that 53% of white adults strongly favor it, compared with 86% of Black adults, 71% of Hispanic adults, and 83% of Asian adults [image4]. Democrats are also more likely to favor making Election Day a national holiday compared with three years ago [1].

In conclusion, views on making Election Day a national holiday differ significantly by race, with White adults being less supportive than Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults.

Republicans and those leaning Republican are significantly more likely to view China as an enemy compared to Democrats and their leaning counterparts [8]. Specifically, 53% of Republicans and Republican-leaners describe China as an enemy, while only 20% of Democrats and Democratic-leaners share the same view [8]. This difference is even more pronounced among conservative Republicans, with nearly two-thirds (64%) labeling China as an enemy, compared to just 37% of moderate or liberal Republicans [8].
![Nearly two-thirds of conservative Republicans view  China as an ‘enemy’ – far more than other groups](image3)
Nearly two-thirds of conservative Republicans view China as an 'enemy', a perception far more prevalent than in other groups[11]. Democrats are more prone to classify China as a competitor, with 65% describing the relationship in this way [10].

In conclusion, perceptions of China as an "enemy" are significantly higher among Republicans, especially conservative Republicans, compared to Democrats and those who lean Democratic.

There are significant differences in opinions on the pace of lifting COVID-19 restrictions based on political affiliation and racial group. A large majority of Democrats (93% of liberal Democrats and 88% of conservative and moderate Democrats) express concern that state restrictions have been lifted too quickly [11].
![Democrats were more likely than Republicans to say restrictions are lifted too quickly.](image7)
 In contrast, Republicans are more divided, with a slight majority (53%) saying restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough, while 45% believe they have been lifted too quickly [6]. Conservative Republicans (60%) are more likely to say restrictions are not being lifted quickly enough, whereas a similar share of moderate and liberal Republicans (57%) express more concern that restrictions have been lifted too quickly [6].

In terms of racial differences, about eight-in-ten Black adults (84%) and seven-in-ten Hispanic adults (72%) are more concerned that states have been lifting restrictions too quickly, a view shared by a narrower majority of white adults (65%) [12].

Overall, Democrats and Black and Hispanic individuals are more likely to believe that restrictions have been lifted too quickly, while Republicans, especially conservative Republicans, are more likely to think restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough.

Americans and Germans hold distinct views on international organizations, with Germans generally showing more positive opinions.

![Germans are more favorable toward the EU than Americans.](image4)
A similar, though less pronounced, gap exists for the UN and NATO, with Germans having a more favorable view of these organizations as well. The difference is quite small for NATO (+5) [image4]. There is greater consensus on the UN and NATO, though notably, Germans tend to think more highly of these organizations than Americans. About one-in-five Americans express no opinion of either the EU or NATO [8].

In summary, Germans generally have a more favorable view of international organizations like the EU and NATO compared to Americans.

Public opinion on automated criminal risk scores is divided, with a range of reasons for both acceptance and opposition.

Some people find automated criminal risk scores acceptable because they believe these systems could be more fair and unbiased compared to human judgment [3]. There is the idea that objective criteria can lead to more equitable outcomes, particularly for groups that might face subjective bias in the current system [3]. It’s also considered acceptable if it’s not the only factor [6].
![Among those who say acceptable, % who give these as the main reasons](image4)

On the other hand, many find these scores unacceptable for several key reasons. A major concern is that such systems cannot fully capture the nuances of individual circumstances or account for personal growth and change [10, 11]. Some, therefore, highlight the continuing need for human involvement in the process [11].
![Among those who say NOT acceptable, % who give these as the main reasons](image4)

In conclusion, the main reasons for accepting automated criminal risk scores include the potential for increased fairness and objectivity, while the main reasons for not accepting them center on concerns about the system's inability to account for individual circumstances and the importance of human judgment in such decisions.

The data reveals a clear trend of diminishing Hispanic identity across generations, contrasting sharply with how non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry identify themselves.

Among self-identified Hispanics, the connection to their ancestral national origins weakens as immigrant roots become more distant. Eight-in-ten immigrants (82%) feel connected to their country of origin, which decreases to 69% in the second generation and significantly drops to 44% by the third generation [9].
![Country of Hispanic/
origin/heritage Latino](image2)
This generational shift is also reflected in the composition of social networks. The majority (77%) of immigrant Latinos report that most of their friends are Latinos. This percentage decreases to 55% among second-generation self-identified Latinos and further to 37% among the third or higher generation [5].
![Foreign born](image4)
The likelihood of having a Hispanic spouse also diminishes across generations. While 93% of married immigrant Hispanics have a Hispanic spouse, this number falls to 63% among the second generation and only 35% among the third generation [6].
![Foreign born](image6)
Experiences with Hispanic cultural celebrations during childhood follow a similar downward trend. Half (49%) of second-generation self-identified Hispanics report frequent attendance at such events, compared to 35% of the third or higher generation [12].
![=Often Sometimes Rarely Never](image1)
In summary, heritage identification among self-identified Hispanics significantly decreases across generations, with fewer individuals maintaining strong connections to their ancestral origins, social networks, and cultural practices as they move further from their immigrant roots.

There's a clear trend of increasing negativity towards the opposing party among Republicans, Democrats, and independents leaning towards either party over the past two decades [2]. Intense dislike of the opposing party has surged among partisans, with a similar trajectory among independents who lean towards the Republican and Democratic parties [4].

Specifically, the share of Democratic-leaning independents with a very unfavorable opinion of the Republican Party has more than quadrupled between 1994 and 2018 (from 8% to 37%) [11]. A similar trend is evident in how Republican-leaning independents view the Democratic Party, with very unfavorable opinions increasing from 15% in 1994 to 39% in 2018 [11].

![Republican Party](image8)

Currently, 87% of Republicans view the Democratic Party unfavorably, and 81% of Republican-leaning independents share this negative view [1]. Similarly, 88% of Democrats and 84% of Democratic-leaning independents view the Republican Party unfavorably [1]. These unfavorable impressions are at or near all-time highs in both parties [1].

Although the share of independents who view both parties negatively has declined in recent years, there was a point in 2015 when more than a third (36%) of independents viewed both parties unfavorably [8].

In conclusion, unfavorable views of both the Republican and Democratic parties have generally increased over time among Republicans, Democrats, and party-leaning independents.

Public opinion regarding anti-terror policies shifted significantly between 2004 and 2015. Initially, there was fluctuation, but by December 2015, a clear trend emerged where a majority felt the policies had not gone far enough to protect the country.

In the period between 2004 and 2013, public opinion varied, with concerns about civil liberties restrictions sometimes outweighing concerns about protection. However, following Edward Snowden's leaks in 2013, there was a notable drop in concern about government overreach in restricting civil liberties [5].

By December 2015, the balance of opinion changed. Twice as many people (56%) believed that anti-terrorism policies had not gone far enough to protect the country, compared to those who thought they had gone too far in restricting civil liberties (28%) [10]. This indicates that concern about protection clearly surpassed the concerns about civil liberty. A similar trend can be observed visually:

![Not gone far enough to protect country](image8)

In addition, the public's assessment of the government's performance in minimizing the terrorist threat has reached its lowest point since September 2001 [6].

In conclusion, from 2004 to 2015, public opinion shifted towards a greater concern that anti-terrorism policies were not adequately protecting the country, with concerns over civil liberties diminishing, especially after 2013.

From 1870 to 1890, Hamilton County experienced a population explosion. In 1870, the population was only 130, but it dramatically increased to 8,267 by 1880 and peaked at 14,096 in 1890 [1]. This is visually represented in a table showing the population data for those years.

![Hamilton County Population Growth 1870-2000](image2)

Several factors contributed to this rapid growth. The Homestead Act of 1862, which offered 160 acres of land to settlers who would live on and improve it, drew many people to Nebraska [5]. The completion of the Transcontinental Railroad also made the area more accessible and attractive for settlement [5]. Early settlers in Hamilton County primarily came from Missouri, Iowa, Illinois, Ohio, and the New England states, with later immigrants arriving from Germany, Sweden, England, and Russia [2].
These ethnic groups tended to settle in specific areas of the county, such as the Danes in the northeast, Swedes in the northwest, and Irish, Bohemians, and Germans in the southwest [2].
![Ethnic Settlements in Hamilton County](image3)

After reaching its peak in 1890, Hamilton County's population began to decline slowly. The number of farms has steadily declined since 1900, which contribute to the population decline. In 1900, over 2,000 individual farms were located in Hamilton County [6]. By 2002, the number of farms had declined to 603 [6].

In conclusion, Hamilton County's population surged between 1870 and 1890 due to the Homestead Act and the Transcontinental Railroad, then gradually declined over the next century.

Americans express strong support for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs. This policy is favored by 85% of Americans, with nearly half (47%) strongly favoring it [4]. The support is consistent across party lines, with the vast majority of Americans, regardless of party affiliation, supporting this idea [3].
![If machines were limited to doing dangerous or unhealthy jobs](image7)
Compared to other policies, such as a guaranteed income or a national service program, the support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs is notably higher [6, 10]. While majorities also support a guaranteed income (60%) and a national service program (58%), the support is less pronounced than the support for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs [6].
![All citizens guaranteed a basic income](image8)
In essence, there is a clear preference among Americans for restricting the use of automation to tasks that are hazardous to human health, surpassing the support for other proposed policy interventions aimed at mitigating the impact of automation [12].

Americans overwhelmingly favor limiting machines to dangerous and unhealthy jobs compared to other automation policies.

A Pew Research Center survey conducted from May 1-15, 2017, explored public attitudes toward driverless vehicles and their potential impact [1, 3]. Regarding the number of people killed or injured in traffic accidents, a portion of respondents believed the number would not decrease if driverless vehicles became widespread.

Specifically, 30% of the public expects that traffic fatalities will actually *increase* if driverless vehicles become more common, and another 31% expect that they will neither increase nor decrease [6].

In 2008, a substantial majority of both Barack Obama's voters (78%) and John McCain's voters (76%) believed that their respective party leaders in Washington should collaborate with the other party, even if it meant potentially disappointing their supporters [1]. A similar sentiment was echoed in 2012, with 56% of Obama voters and 90% of Romney backers wanting Obama to work with Republicans [6].

However, the political climate shifted significantly by 2016. While 83% of Trump voters expressed that Democratic leaders should work with Trump, only 35% of Clinton voters felt the same [5]. A considerable majority of Clinton voters (63%) preferred that Democratic leaders stand up to Trump, even if it hindered progress [5].
![Should Democratic leaders work with Trump or stand up to Trump?](image7)
This demonstrates the partisan divide on whether Democratic leaders should work with Republicans is larger this year than in 2008 [12]. In 2008, after Obama’s first victory, 58% of McCain voters said Republican leaders should try their best to work with Obama [7]. Comparatively, after Trump won, only 32% want the party’s leaders to work with Trump if it means disappointing Democrats [2]. Democratic support for cooperation with the president-elect today is substantially less than GOP support for working with Obama eight years ago [4].

The difference highlights a significant increase in partisanship and a decreased willingness among Democratic voters to compromise and collaborate with the opposing party's leader.
In summary, voter opinions shifted significantly between 2008 and 2016, with a greater emphasis on partisan opposition in 2016 compared to the more cooperative sentiment in 2008.

Americans and Germans have differing views on national defense spending, both for their own countries and for their allies, with shifts in opinion between 2017 and 2019.

Half of Americans in 2019 believed that European allies should maintain their current defense spending levels, a change from 2017 when 45% thought European allies should increase spending [10]. This shift is further illustrated by data showing a decrease in the percentage of Americans who think European allies should increase spending on national defense.
![Should our European allies  spending on national defense? Should Germany  spending on national defense?](image6)

Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain their own country's defense spending, with about 40% supporting each view in 2019 [11]. This also represents a change from 2017 when half of Germans were satisfied with existing spending, while only a third favored increases [11].

Views on this issue have changed in both countries.
![Should our European allies  spending on national defense? Should Germany  spending on national defense?](image6)

In the U.S., there's a partisan divide, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe, though the share of Republicans with this view has declined since 2017 [7]. Fewer Americans, in general, are advocating for increased European defense spending.
![Republican/Lean Rep Democrat/Lean Dem](image2)

In summary, American opinion shifted towards favoring the maintenance of current defense spending levels by European allies, while Germans are split between increasing and maintaining their own defense spending, with both countries showing changes in these views from 2017 to 2019.

The sector with the largest potential for CO2 emissions reduction at the lowest cost (0-50 Euros/ton) is the "Iron and Steel" sector. ![Construction shows various sectors and their potential for CO2 reduction, categorized by cost.](image5) This is visible in the image, where the "Iron and Steel" sector has the largest bubble within the 0-50 Euros/ton range. Therefore, the Iron and Steel sector presents the most substantial opportunity for reducing CO2 emissions at the lowest cost (0-50 Euros/ton) compared to other sectors.

*   Terrorism increased from 1% to 18% [6].
*   Defense/National security went from 2% to 8% [6].
*   ISIS/War in Iraq/War in Syria rose from 2% to 7%[6].
*   The Economy (general) decreased from 14% to 9% [6].

Racial identification varies significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics. Among foreign-born Hispanics, a large majority (78%) believe that strangers on the street would perceive them as Hispanic or Latino [1]. This perception decreases to two-thirds among second-generation Hispanics [1].

![Most Hispanics say passersby see them as Hispanic, though that share falls across generations; 59% of self-identified non-Hispanics say they’re seen as white](image1)

By the third or higher generation, the share drops to 46% [1]. This trend indicates that the closer individuals are to their immigrant roots, the more likely they are to be perceived as Hispanic or Latino, while those in later generations are less likely to be seen as such.

The survey data further supports that the sample size of 1,500 Total Latinos, has a Margin of error of +/- 3.3% points [4].

In conclusion, racial identification as Hispanic decreases across generations, with foreign-born Hispanics most likely to be perceived as Hispanic, followed by second-generation, and then third or higher generation Hispanics.

There are significant differences in how racial and ethnic groups in STEM jobs perceive workplace discrimination and fairness. Black STEM workers are considerably more likely to report experiencing discrimination due to their race or ethnicity compared to other groups. Specifically, 62% of Black STEM workers report such experiences, in contrast to 44% of Asians, 42% of Hispanics, and only 13% of Whites [8, 11].

![Perceptions of discrimination in STEM jobs vary significantly across racial and ethnic groups.](image5)

Blacks in STEM are also more likely to believe that discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major reason for the underrepresentation of Blacks and Hispanics in STEM [7, 10]. This view contrasts sharply with those of White and Asian STEM workers, among whom only about a quarter agree that discrimination is a major factor [7, 10]. Specifically, 72% of Black STEM workers see discrimination as a major issue, compared to just 27% of Whites and 28% of Asians [7].

![Disparities in STEM representation are perceived differently among various racial and ethnic groups.](image1)

Furthermore, when it comes to fairness in the workplace, only 43% of Black STEM workers believe that Blacks are usually treated fairly during recruitment, and 37% believe this is the case for promotion and advancement opportunities [6]. This is significantly lower than the perceptions of White STEM workers, the majority of whom (78% for hiring and 75% for advancement) believe Blacks are usually treated fairly [6].

In conclusion, perceptions of workplace discrimination and fairness differ significantly among racial/ethnic groups in STEM jobs, with Black STEM workers reporting higher rates of discrimination and lower perceptions of fairness compared to their White, Asian, and Hispanic counterparts.

Several scenarios illustrate how Caltrain service improvements could affect the peak hour train car requirement. Currently, Caltrain operates with 5 trains per hour, each with 5 cars, totaling 25 peak hour train cars [1].

![Scenario Peak service | Peak hour train cars
Today 5x5 25
Metrolink used cars 6x5 30
Electrification 6x6 36
Longer platforms 6x8 48
Increase frequency (w/HSR) | 8x8 64](image4)

One scenario involves using second-hand cars from Metrolink, which would increase the number of trains per hour to 6, while still using 5-car trains. This configuration results in 30 peak hour train cars [4]. Another scenario is electrification, which allows for 6 trains per hour with 6 cars each, totaling 36 peak hour train cars. By extending the platforms, Caltrain could run longer trains, specifically 8 cars per train, and maintain 6 trains per hour. The combination would increase peak hour capacity to 48 cars [2]. Finally, by increasing the frequency and the number of train cars to 8 and 8. The peak hour train cars would be 64 [8].

The peak hour train car requirement changes from 25 to 30, 36, 48, and 64 with different scenarios for Caltrain service improvement.

A quarter of the public believes that neither the Republican nor the Democratic Party upholds "high ethical standards," while 47% believe it applies to one party but not the other, and 17% believe it applies to both [7].

Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say "high ethical standards" does not describe the GOP or the Democratic Party; 43% say it describes one and not the other, and 17% think it describes both [5]. Fewer of those with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less education (20%) think neither party has high ethical standards [12].
![Views of the two political parties on ethics](image4)
Majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describe their party as having high ethical standards [3]. About a third of independents (34%), including equal shares of Republican leaners and Democratic leaners (33% each), say neither party has high ethical standards [1].
![Party ethics](image7)
The survey was conducted from April 25 to May 1, 2018, involving 1,503 participants, with varying margins of error for different subgroups.
![Information of survey](image1)

In summary, perceptions of ethical standards vary significantly, with college graduates being the most critical, while majorities within each party view their own party positively, and independents are more likely to see neither party as having high ethical standards.

A significant majority of U.S. adults, 68%, find the use of automated personal finance scores by companies to be unacceptable [8].

The primary concerns cited are:

*   **Privacy Violation**: 26% of those who find it unacceptable believe that collecting this data violates people's privacy [11].
*   **Inaccurate Representation**: 20% say that someone's online data does not accurately represent them [10].
*   **Unfairness and Discrimination**: 15% feel that it is potentially unfair or discriminatory to rely on this type of score [1, 6].
     ![Doesn't represent person accurately](image6)

These concerns reflect a broader skepticism about computer programs and automated decision-making, with worries about human bias, failure to capture nuance, and the overall fairness of these systems [3, 12]. These apprehensions highlight the public's discomfort with the collection and utilization of personal data in financial contexts, and the potential for such systems to misrepresent individuals or lead to discriminatory outcomes [5].

In conclusion, the primary concerns of U.S. adults regarding the use of automated personal finance scores by companies are privacy violations, inaccurate representation of individuals, and the potential for unfairness and discrimination.

Internet and broadband usage among seniors decreases significantly around the age of 75 [7, 8]. Specifically, 74% of seniors in the 65-69 age group go online, and 65% have broadband at home [9]. However, these numbers drop off considerably for older age groups.

Asians are overrepresented in the STEM workforce, especially among college-educated workers [1]. 17% of college-educated STEM workers are Asian, compared with 10% of all workers with a college degree [2]. The survey was conducted from April 25 to May 1, 2018, among a national sample of 1,503 adults [3]. 36% of adults rated the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as poor [10].

To calculate the number of adults who rated the ethical standards as poor, multiply the total number of respondents by the percentage who rated them as poor:
1,503 (total adults) * 0.36 (percentage rating as poor) = 541.08.

![Excellent](image4)

Therefore, among the adults surveyed, approximately 541 rated the Trump administration's ethical standards as poor.

The percentage of the IT budget allocated to data security varies across different tiers of businesses. Specifically, the breakdown of IT budget spending on data security is detailed for various tiers [6].

![Data Security Budget Allocation Across Tiers](image6)

Tier 3, which comprises businesses with revenue under $500 million, allocates the highest percentage of their IT budget to data security, at 15.1% [6]. Of this allocation, 42.3% is taken up by PCI compliance within Tier 3 businesses [6]. In contrast, Tier 1 (Over $1 Billion) and Tier 2 ($500 million - $1 Billion) allocate 13.8% and 13.3% of their IT budgets to data security, respectively [6].

Tier 3 businesses allocate the highest percentage of their IT budget to data security.

Men are more likely than women to report seeing mean or bullying behavior on social media platforms [8]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely than men to report seeing kind or supportive behavior [8].
![People being
People being kind or
mean or bullying supportive Equal mix of both](image2)
However, the largest shares of both men (52%) and women (56%) say they typically see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [8]. In terms of attempts to spread or correct misinformation, men are around twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [11].

Regarding the types of content frequently encountered, the most common are posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58% of users see this frequently) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59% see this frequently) [7].

or exaggerated](image3)

A majority (57%) of voters in 2016 believed that news organizations had too much influence on the outcome of the presidential election [7]. This perception has fluctuated over time, but the 2016 election saw the highest percentage of voters with this view since 2000 [7].

![7 13 Too little 39 About the a bec 45 os ie right amount 57 Too much GGoingaibtig. 1992 1996 2000 2004 2008 2012 2016](image2)

The share saying news organizations had too much influence on the outcome of the presidential election is the highest it has been since 2000, while the share of those saying the press had about the right amount of influence is the lowest in Pew Research Center polling going back to 1992 [7]. In 2004, after George W. Bush's reelection, 45% of Bush voters believed news organizations had too much influence [4]. In comparison, 62% of Trump voters, 69% of Romney voters and 77% of McCain voters say the press had too much influence following their election losses [4].

In conclusion, the belief that news organizations exert "too much" influence on presidential elections has generally increased since 2000, reaching a peak in 2016.

The map shows the locations of various ISRO (Indian Space Research Organisation) centers and facilities across India [12]. These include:

*   **Research Centers**: Such as the Physical Research Laboratory (PRL) in Ahmedabad and the National Atmospheric Research Laboratory (NARL) in Tirupati [11].
*   **Spaceports**: Like the Satish Dhawan Space Centre (SDSC) SHAR in Sriharikota [5].
*   **Launch Vehicle Development Centers**: Including the Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC) in Thiruvananthapuram [7].
*   **Satellite Development Centers**: Such as the ISRO Satellite Centre (ISAC) in Bengaluru [10].
*   **Telemetry, Tracking, and Command Centers**: Like the ISRO Telemetry, Tracking and Command Network (ISTRAC) in Bengaluru [8].
*   **Remote Sensing Centers**: Including the National Remote Sensing Centre (NRSC) in Hyderabad [6].
*   **Other Facilities**: Such as the Master Control Facilities, Space Application Centers and various ISRO offices.

![Organisation](image6)

The map depicts the organizational structure under the Prime Minister, including the Space Commission and the Department of Space.

![The map in the report shows ISRO centers](image8)

The map in the report shows the locations of ISRO centers.

The breakdown of total emissions by percentage weight reveals the major contributors to air pollution. The largest contributor is vehicle traffic, accounting for a significant portion of the total emissions. ![Vehicel Traffic is the top source according to the total emission in percent by weight.](image7) Specifically, vehicle traffic accounts for 54% of the total emissions [7].

Following vehicle traffic, the next major source of emissions is power generation.![Power Generation is the second top source according to the total emission in percent by weight.](image7) Power generation is responsible for 19% of the total emissions [7].

The third-largest contributor is categorized as "Other Sources." ![Other Sources is the third top source according to the total emission in percent by weight.](image7) This category encompasses various emission sources and accounts for 11% of the total emissions [7].

The top 3 sources by emission percentage weight, in descending order, are Vehicle Traffic (54%), Power Generation (19%), and Other Sources (11%).

Many seniors face physical challenges when using new digital devices [8]. Specifically, 23% of older adults report having a physical or health condition that makes reading difficult, and 29% have a disability or chronic disease that prevents them from fully participating in daily activities [8].  

![Physical or health condition makes reading difficult or challenging, Disability, handicap, or chronic disease that prevents full participation in work, school, or other activities](image4)

These physical challenges create significant barriers to technology adoption among older adults [9]. Groups with these challenges are less likely to go online (49% vs. 66%), have broadband at home (38% vs. 53%), own a cell phone (69% vs. 82%), and own a smartphone (13% vs. 22%) compared to seniors without such challenges [6]. These health conditions, such as that make it difficult to read, can also be obstacles to use the technologies [9, 11].

In conclusion, physical health conditions significantly reduce technology use among older adults compared to the general adult population.

There's a difference in how Republicans and Democrats view the proposal for redistricting commissions [10]. Democrats are more likely than Republicans to favor replacing state legislatures with independent commissions for drawing congressional maps [4].

The specific breakdown shows that:
*   More adults approve (49%) than disapprove (13%) of a Democratic proposal to require commissions with equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans to draw congressional district maps, rather than state legislatures; a sizable share of adults (38%) say they are not sure about this proposal [4].
*   Republicans and Republican leaners are somewhat more likely to disapprove of these non-legislative commissions than are Democrats (19% and 8% respectively), but they are also more likely than Democrats to say they are not sure either way (42% vs. 32%) [9].
*    The proposal is described as requiring all states to assemble committees with equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans for determining the state's congressional maps.
![Disapprove Approve = Not sure](image7)

In conclusion, Democrats are more likely to approve of the redistricting proposal compared to Republicans.

Independents who do not lean toward a party are more inclined to hold unfavorable views of both the Republican and Democratic parties [11]. Specifically, 37% of independents who do not lean toward either party express unfavorable opinions of both [1].

![Unfavorable to both](image8)

In contrast, a smaller percentage (17%) of the general population feels unfavorably toward both parties [12]. Although, at one point in 2015, the percentage of independent who viewed both parties unfavorably reached 36% [8].

Therefore, independents with no lean are most likely to have unfavorable opinions of both major parties.

From 2020 to 2021, several issues related to China saw a marked increase in concern among Americans. ![2020-2021 change in concern among Americans on China related issues](image6)

The frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations during childhood varies significantly across immigrant generations. Among foreign-born, self-identified Hispanics, 59% reported that their parents often took them to such celebrations [12]. This is visually represented in the data, which shows a high percentage (43%) for "Often" in this group. ![`Often` responses are predominant among foreign-born, self-identified Hispanics.](image1)

For second-generation, self-identified Hispanics, 49% reported that their immigrant parents often took them to Hispanic cultural celebrations during their childhood [3]. The data shows a decrease in the "Often" category and an increase in the "Sometimes" category compared to the foreign-born group. ![`Sometimes` responses increase in the second generation, while `Often` decreases.](image1)

Among third or higher generation self-identified Hispanics, only 35% reported the same frequency of attendance at cultural celebrations [3]. The data continues the trend, with a further decrease in "Often" responses and a noticeable increase in "Rarely" and "Never" responses. ![`Rarely` and `Never` responses become more prevalent in the third or higher generation.](image1)

The experiences of non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry differ greatly. Only 9% reported that their parents frequently took them to Latino cultural celebrations, while 60% said this never happened [2].

In summary, the frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations in childhood decreases significantly across immigrant generations, from 59% for foreign-born, self-identified Hispanics to 35% for third or higher generation, self-identified Hispanics.

Female representation varies significantly across different STEM occupational clusters [9]. Women are a majority in health-related occupations, constituting 75% of healthcare practitioners and technicians [7]. However, they are underrepresented in other STEM fields, particularly in computer jobs and engineering [9].

Specifically, women make up 47% of life scientists and 46% of math workers, which is close to their overall representation in the workforce (47%) [6]. Their representation is lower among physical scientists (39%) [6]. The lowest shares are in engineering, at 14%, and computer occupations, at 25% [6].
![Women's representation in STEM jobs varies by occupational subgroup, with the lowest in engineering and the highest in health-related fields.](image4)

The share of women in computer occupations has decreased from 32% in 1990 to 25% today [11].
![Shows how the representation of women changed in STEM jobs from 1990 to 2016.](image1)
Within engineering, some of the lowest shares of women are found in mechanical and electrical engineering, at 8% and 9% respectively [4].

In summary, female representation in STEM varies widely by occupation, with the highest representation in health-related jobs and the lowest in engineering and computer jobs.

Black STEM workers are more likely to report experiences of workplace discrimination due to race than their white counterparts [9]. Specifically, 62% of blacks in STEM say they have experienced discrimination at work because of their race or ethnicity, compared with just 13% of whites in STEM jobs [7]. This disparity is visually represented in the data, showing a significant difference between the experiences of Black and White STEM workers [7].
![Among those in STEM jobs who are ...](image1)
Blacks in STEM jobs are also less convinced than white STEM workers that black employees are treated fairly in hiring and promotions [5]. Only 43% of blacks in STEM believe that blacks are usually treated fairly during recruitment, and 37% believe this is the case for promotion and advancement opportunities [5]. In contrast, most white STEM workers believe that blacks are usually treated fairly in these processes, with 78% agreeing for hiring and 75% for advancement [5].

Furthermore, blacks (40%) and Asians (31%) in STEM jobs are more likely than white STEM workers (5%) to say their race or ethnicity has made it harder to find success [8].
Blacks working in STEM jobs share similar beliefs with other racial/ethnic minority, who believe that members of their racial or ethnic group are usually treated fairly [6].

In conclusion, there are significant disparities in the experiences of discrimination and perceptions of fairness between black and white STEM workers, with blacks reporting higher rates of discrimination and lower perceptions of fairness in the workplace.

Pre-training the word embeddings in source and/or target languages generally helps to increase BLEU scores [12]. The gains from pre-training can vary significantly based on the language pair and the amount of training data available.

For higher-resource languages, pre-training provides consistent gains of approximately 3 BLEU points [2].
![Pre-training consistently improves BLEU scores for higher-resource languages by about 3 points.](image2)
For extremely low-resource languages, the gains can be either small or very large. For example, GL (Galician) achieves a gain of up to 11 BLEU points, while AZ (Azerbaijani) and BE (Belarusian) show smaller gains [2].
![Effect of pre-training on multilingual translation into English.](image3)
Pre-training helps to improve the translation accuracy for all vocabulary and performs better for low frequency words [7]. Pre-training not only helps the model capture rarer vocabulary, but also makes sentence grammatically well-formed [1]. For example, the model with the best pre-training could translate person's name and multi-word phrases successfully, which approved that pre-trained embeddings could provide better representations of less frequent concepts for low-resource languages [1].
![Pre-training improves translation, especially for less frequent words and phrases.](image8)
The effect of pre-training can also be influenced by the similarity of the source and target languages. Pairs with higher similarity, like GL/PT, tend to show larger gains [10].

In summary, pre-training generally improves BLEU scores, with the magnitude of improvement depending on language resources, language similarity.

The inclusion of reference translations significantly impacts the performance of the COMET-RANK metric, with variations observed across different language pairs involving English [7].

The data shows that when COMET-RANK uses both reference and source, it achieves higher Kendall's Tau (τ) correlation scores compared to when it uses only the reference [7].
![Effect of reference inclusion on COMET-RANK metric](image7)
For example, in the 'en-cs' language pair, COMET-RANK (ref. only) has a score of 0.660, while COMET-RANK with both reference and source has a score of 0.711, showing an increase of 0.051 [7]. Similar improvements are observed across other language pairs, such as 'en-de' (0.764 to 0.799), 'en-fi' (0.630 to 0.671), and 'en-tr' (0.539 to 0.563) [7].

The degree of improvement, indicated by Δτ, varies across language pairs [7]. For language pairs with English as the source, the improvements are smaller (e.g., 0.051 for 'en-cs', 0.035 for 'en-de') compared to those with English as the target (e.g., 0.107 for 'cs-en', 0.155 for 'de-en') [7, 12]. This difference is may be caused by the higher quality of multilingual training of the model, enhancing the model's capacity to leverage source information, which resulted in that including English shows a smaller improvement [12].

In conclusion, the inclusion of reference translations positively affects the COMET-RANK metric, with larger improvements in language pairs where English is the target compared to those where English is the source.

In relative evaluations, annotator agreement levels for Chameleon compared against other models are detailed as follows [4]:

![Annotator Agreement Levels](image5)

The data reveals that in comparisons with Gemini-+, all three annotators agree in 31.5% of cases, two agree in 58.1%, and there is no agreement in 10.3% [4]. Against GPT-4V+, unanimous agreement occurs in 35.4% of cases, two annotators agree in 55.2%, and 9.3% show no agreement [4]. When compared with the original responses from Gemini, all three annotators agree on 30.2% of cases, two agree in 59.3%, and there is no agreement in 10.5% of cases. Lastly, with GPT-4V, unanimous agreement is observed in 28.6% of cases, two-way agreement in 58.3%, and no agreement in 13.1% of cases [4].

This indicates that in many instances, Chameleon performs comparably to other baseline models, which complicates the relative evaluation process [4]. The relatively high percentage of cases with two out of three annotators agreeing suggests moderate inter-annotator reliability, while the consistent presence of around 10% disagreement highlights inherent subjectivity in evaluating model performance [4].

In conclusion, annotator agreement levels show moderate consistency, with a significant portion of evaluations having two of three annotators agreeing, and about 10% showing no agreement, suggesting challenges in relative performance evaluations of Chameleon [4].

The study investigates the impact of the number of demonstration samples on the Micro-F1 performance, both with and without logical constraints, using the MAVEN-ERE and CTB datasets. The findings reveal a consistent trend:

*   Increasing the number of demonstrations from 1 to 5 results in a noticeable improvement in Micro-F1 score [9].
*   However, further increasing the demonstrations (e.g., to 10 or 20) yields only limited additional improvements [4].
*    Incorporating logical constraints into the LLM instructions provides stable improvements in performance, and this effect is more pronounced with a greater number of demonstrations [4].

These trends can be clearly visualized in the provided figure: `![Micro-F1 scores and logical inconsistency percentages across different numbers of demonstration samples and iterations.](image1)`

The graph shows that the Micro-F1 score increases significantly when the number of demonstration samples increases from 1 to 5, but the improvement plateaus afterward, for both MAVEN-ERE and CTB datasets, regardless of whether logical constraints are used [4].

In summary, increasing the number of demonstrations initially improves Micro-F1 performance, but the benefit diminishes beyond a certain point (around 5 demonstrations), and adding logical constraints improves the score and with the increment of demonstrations, the improvement is stable.

The error analysis of Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA reveals several key error types. The main categories of errors are: Context Loss, Reasoning Error, Principle Error, Factual Error, Math Error, StepBack, RAG, and Scoring Error [4, 5, 6, 10].

A significant portion of the errors are attributed to Reasoning Errors and RAG failing to retrieve relevant information [3, 10]. Specifically, Reasoning Errors account for a large fraction of the issues, indicating difficulties in the intermediate reasoning steps before reaching the final answer [5].

![Error distribution for Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA](image7)

As the image illustrates, in TimeQA, the most prevalent errors with Step-Back prompting is Reasoning Error, followed by, RAG, StepBack error and finally, Scoring Error [10].

The main error types in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA are Reasoning Error, RAG, StepBack, and Scoring Error.

The Entity-GCN model's performance is evaluated in comparison to other models, including BiDAF, FastQA, Coref-GRU, MHPGM, Weaver, and MHQA-GRN, on the unmasked test set [7]. The Entity-GCN with coreference (single model) achieves an accuracy of 66.4 on the Unmasked Test [8]. The results show that Entity-GCN outperforms all previous work by over 2% points [9]. Specifically, the full Entity-GCN model achieves over a 2% improvement over the best previously-published results, and an ensemble model brings a further 3.6% of improvement [10].

![Test Results](image8)

In conclusion, the Entity-GCN with coreference achieves a score of 66.4, outperforming previously published results, but is lower than the version without coreference and the ensemble model.

The Anchor Re-weighting method significantly enhances the performance of In-Context Learning (ICL). In contrast, "Vanilla In-Context Learning (1-shot per class)" achieves an average accuracy of only 51.90 across the same datasets [3].

Therefore, the Anchor Re-weighting method improves the performance of vanilla ICL by an average of 16.74.

Let's analyze each correction strategy based on the provided information:

*   **Training-time Correction:** This strategy focuses on rectifying the model during its training phase [8]. It can utilize human feedback, a reward model, or automated feedback to optimize the model [8]. A common strategy for leveraging automated feedback is self-training [4]. Direct optimization with human feedback is an ideal scenario for this strategy [7].
*   **Generation-time Correction:** This method uses automated feedback to correct errors during the generation process [6]. It is necessary when model parameters are inaccessible [12]. There are two main strategies: Generate-then-Rank and Feedback-Guided Decoding [12].
     ![The illustration of generate-then-rank and feedback-guided decoding](image1)
*   **Post-hoc Correction:** This strategy refines the model output after it has been generated, without updating the model parameters [2]. It allows for diverse natural language feedback [1]. Key strategies include Self-Correction, Correction with External Feedback, and Multi-Agent Debate [1].
    ![Key post-hoc correction strategies](image5)

The survey categorizes various correction methodologies into Training-Time Correction, Generation-Time Correction, and Post-hoc Correction [10]. The image regarding "Post-hoc Correction" presents an extensive table.

![Post-hoc Correction](image3)

The numerous entries in this table indicate a significant body of work dedicated to this strategy.

Therefore, among the three, Post-hoc Correction has the most representative papers in the survey.

The Tversky Index (TI) uses hyperparameters, \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\), to control the tradeoff between false negatives and false positives [4]. Experiments were conducted on the Chinese OntoNotes 4.0 NER and English QuoRef MRC datasets to observe the effect of these hyperparameters [4]. The results, specifically focusing on how varying \(\alpha\) (with \(\beta\) set as \(1 - \alpha\)) affects the F1 score, are presented in a detailed table [11].

The data reveals that the F1 score is significantly influenced by the value of \(\alpha\), and this influence varies between the two datasets [4].
![The effect of the parameter alpha on F1 score is shown, with optimal values highlighted for each dataset.](image1)
For the Chinese OntoNotes 4.0 dataset, the highest F1 score of 84.67 is achieved when \(\alpha\) is set to 0.6. For the English QuoRef dataset, the optimal \(\alpha\) value is 0.4, resulting in the highest F1 score of 68.44 [4]. The performance varies significantly with different \(\alpha\) values, underlining the importance of these hyperparameters in the Tversky Index [4].

The optimal \(\alpha\) value for the Chinese OntoNotes 4.0 dataset is 0.6, yielding an F1 score of 84.67, while the optimal \(\alpha\) for the English QuoRef dataset is 0.4, achieving an F1 score of 68.44.

Let's analyze the differences between the multitask and single-task models, focusing on decoder attention, based on Figures 1a and 1b.

Figure 1a depicts a single-task model. ![single-task](image6)
 It consists of a recurrent encoder, attention mechanism, and a recurrent decoder [11]. The decoder's attention is focused solely on the encoder's output.

Figure 1b shows a standard encoder-decoder multitask model. ![multitask](image6)
 It utilizes a shared encoder for two output sequences but incorporates separate attentions and decoders for each task [12].

The key difference lies in the number of attention mechanisms. The single-task model has one attention mechanism connecting the decoder to the encoder. The multitask model, however, has two separate attention mechanisms – one for each decoder, and both connected to the shared encoder.

Therefore, the multitask model in Figure 1b differs from the single-task model in Figure 1a by having separate attentions for each decoder, while the single-task model only uses one attention.

The RAR (Retrieving And Ranking) pipeline for multimodal retrieval has several key components that work together. Here's a breakdown:

First, a **multimodal retriever** is used to create and store multimodal embeddings from images and text descriptions [9, 11]. This retriever queries a large multimodal external memory or database to find information relevant to the input [9]. It focuses on optimizing retrieval speed through index construction techniques, using the HNSW algorithm for dimensionality reduction to enhance the speed of the retrieval process [7].
![Multimodal Retriever Database Image Feature Embeddings](image1)

Upon receiving an input image, the system retrieves the top-*k* class names most similar to the image [11].

The pipeline integrates a **ranking prompt** to merge the input image with the category information retrieved from memory [5].
![Ranking Prompt Example Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedan](image6)

Then, **MLLMs (Multimodal Large Language Models)** rank these retrieved candidate results, using their internal knowledge combined with retrieved information to make a final prediction [2, 3, 11]. The image regions can be cropped and blurred before input into MLLMs [4].
![Pre-process Embedding & Retrieve](image3)

The main components of the RAR pipeline are the multimodal retriever, the ranking prompt, and the MLLMs, which perform the final ranking.

The authors describe a multi-step reasoning process for causal inference, which is visually represented and detailed in their work. Specifically, the process is broken down into distinct phases:

First, there's a preparation phase, including identifying the causal graph structure, determining the causal query type, formulating the query symbolically, and extracting relevant data from the prompt [5]. These steps are crucial for setting up the problem correctly.

![Preparation steps for causal inference](image6)

Following the preparation, the solution phase involves deducing the estimand using causal inference techniques and then evaluating the estimand to answer the question [5]. The process is summarized as a series of six key steps.

![Key Steps in Causal Inference](image4)

Therefore, the author divided causal inference into six key steps.

The task success rate of the "SL + IL 1000 + RL" model is depicted in comparison to other models over time, with interactive learning sessions.

Initially, the SL (Supervised Learning) model performs poorly, possibly due to compounding errors from the mismatch between offline training and interactive learning dialogue state distributions [10]. When Reinforcement Learning (RL) is applied to the supervised pre-training model (SL + RL), the task success rate improves continuously with more user interactions [5].

However, the "SL + IL 1000 + RL" model, which incorporates 1000 episodes of imitation learning (IL) over the SL model followed by RL optimization, shows a superior performance. Imitation learning helps the model adapt to the dialogue state distribution during user interactions, leading to improved task success rates [5]. It is evident that both the models with imitation learning (SL + IL 500 + RL and SL + IL 1000 + RL) surpass the performance of the models without it (SL Baseline and SL + RL) [5, 8]. The graph indicates that "SL + IL 1000 + RL" model not only achieves a higher task success rate but also learns more effectively over time as the number of interactive learning sessions increases. The overall upward trend shows continuous improvement due to interactive learning.

![Task Success Rate over Time (smoothed)](image8)

Specifically, the chart shows that:
*   **SL Baseline**: Starts low and remains low throughout the sessions.
*   **SL + RL**: Shows improvement over time but plateaus at a lower success rate compared to models with IL.
*   **SL + IL 500 + RL**: Demonstrates a significant improvement over SL + RL, showing the positive impact of imitation learning.
* **SL + IL 1000 + RL**: has the best performance among all.

In conclusion, the "SL + IL 1000 + RL" model outperforms the other models in terms of task success rate over time, demonstrating the effectiveness of combining imitation learning with reinforcement learning.

The SciIE model demonstrates strong performance across various tasks, often outperforming other models in precision, recall, and F1 score.

In entity recognition, SciIE achieves an F1 score of 68.1 on the development set and 64.2 on the test set, surpassing models like LSTM+CRF, LSTM+CRF+ELMo, E2E Rel, and E2E Rel+ELMo [9, image4]. For relation extraction, SciIE's F1 scores are 39.5 (dev) and 39.3 (test), which is superior to the E2E Rel models [9, image4]. In coreference resolution, SciIE also outperforms E2E Coref, achieving F1 scores of 58.0 (dev) and 48.2 (test) [9, image4]. A multi-task version of SciIE (SCIIE) is compared to it's single-task version and ablation models that had specific capabilities removed. We can see that that multi-task version generally outperformed all other models in entity recognition, relation extraction, and coreference resolution [2, image2].

On the SemEval 17 dataset, SciIE shows competitive results, with an overall F1 score of 44.7, outperforming the best SemEval system and matching Luan's model (2017) [11, image7]. Notably, SciIE achieves significant improvements in span identification, confirming the benefit of enumerating spans rather than using BIO tagging [12, image7].

The performance comparison between BERT<sub>BASE</sub> (OURS) and SenseBERT<sub>BASE</sub> reveals interesting trends across various NLP tasks.

On the General Language Understanding Evaluation (GLUE) benchmark, SenseBERT<sub>BASE</sub> performs on par with BERT<sub>BASE</sub> (OURS), achieving an overall score of 77.9 compared to 77.5 [5]. This indicates that SenseBERT gains its lexical semantic knowledge without compromising performance on other downstream tasks [5].
![Performance comparison on various NLP tasks](image1)

However, in tasks requiring a high level of lexical semantic understanding, SenseBERT shows clear improvement. For instance, on the SemEval Supersense Disambiguation (SemEval-SS) task, SenseBERT<sub>BASE</sub> significantly outperforms BERT<sub>BASE</sub>, especially in the Frozen setting [3, 8]. In the "Frozen" setting, SenseBERT<sub>BASE</sub> scores over 10 points higher than BERT<sub>BASE</sub>[2].
![Results on different tasks, comparing SenseBERT and BERT.](image8)
This suggests the word-sense aware pre-training of SenseBERT yields embeddings that contain readily extractable lexical semantic information [3].
![Examples of the SemEval-SS task](image7)
Examples from SemEval-SS, where SenseBERT correctly predicts the supersense while BERT fails, highlight this difference. [12].

For the Word in Context (WiC) task, which also requires word-supersense awareness, SenseBERT<sub>BASE</sub> surpasses even the larger BERT<sub>LARGE</sub> model [6, 8].
![Examples of the Word in Context(WiC) task](image7)

In summary, while both models show similar performance on general NLP tasks, SenseBERT<sub>BASE</sub> demonstrates superior performance in tasks that specifically require lexical semantic understanding, making it better for tasks that are depending on word-supersense awareness.

The Weighted Decoding Response table shows how different weights influence the generated response to the input "Yes, I'm studying law at the moment".
![Example of controlling specificity via weighted decoding](image1)
As the weight (wt NIDF) increases, the responses shift from generic to increasingly specific and eventually nonsensical outputs [1]. A weight of -5.0 produces an incomprehensible response, while a weight of 0.0 gives a generic response [1], [8]. Weights of 3.0 and 7.0 generate more specific responses, and the response with weight of 10.0 becomes nonsensical [1], [8].

In summary, increasing the weight in the Weighted Decoding model for the given input initially leads to more specific responses, but extreme weights result in nonsensical output.

The probability distribution over the two warrants is determined using the softmax function. Specifically, the logits   $z_{0}^{(i)}$   and    $z_{1}^{(i)}$   are passed through a softmax function to obtain the probabilities   $\mathbf{p}^{(i)}\stackrel{\cdot}{=}\mathrm{softmax}\big([z_{0}^{(i)},z_{1}^{(i)}]\big)$ [3, 5]. The logits themselves are generated by a linear layer that processes the CLS vector from the BERT model [2, 8].
![Processing an argument-warrant pair with BERT. The reason (with word pieces of length    $a$  ) and claim (length  b ) together form the ﬁrst utterance, and the warrant (length  $c$  ) is the second. The ﬁnal CLS vector is then passed to a linear layer to calculate the logit  $z_{j}^{(i)}$  .](image8)
The prediction is made by selecting the warrant with the highest probability from this distribution [5].

The function used to determine a probability distribution over the two warrants is softmax.

The impact of Retrieval Augmentation (RA) on model performance varies across different entity categories (Head, Torso, and Tail), with notable improvements in accuracy and reductions in hallucination rates [4].

The performance improvement for torso-to-tail entities far exceeds that of head entities, effectively addressing the challenge of hallucinations in long-tailed entities through retrieval augmentation [11].

In conclusion, Retrieval Augmentation positively impacts accuracy and reduces hallucination rates across all entity categories, with the most significant improvements observed in the Tail category.

The Translation Ranking model, depicted in Figure 2, utilizes the triplet margin loss function [6]. The architecture takes four segments: the source, the reference, a "better" hypothesis, and a "worse" one [6]. These are encoded and a pooling layer is applied [6].
![Translation Ranking model architecture. This architecture receives 4 segments: the source, the reference, a “better” hypothesis, and a “worse” one. These segments are independently encoded using a pre- trained cross-lingual encoder and a pooling layer on top. Finally, using the triplet margin loss ( Schroff et al. , 2015 ) we optimize the resulting embedding space to minimize the distance between the “better” hypothesis and the “anchors” (source and reference). ](image6)
The purpose of this loss is to optimize the embedding space [6]. The optimization works by minimizing the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the "anchors" (which are the source and reference) [6]. During training, the model adjusts the embedding space so the distance between the anchors and the "worse" hypothesis is greater by at least a margin (ε) than the distance between the anchors and the "better" hypothesis [10].

In summary, the purpose of the triplet margin loss in the Translation Ranking model is to optimize the embedding space to minimize the distance between the “better” hypothesis and the “anchors” (source and reference).

"Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback" is a strategy that refines the output of a language model after it has been generated [6]. This is done without updating the model parameters, making it a flexible approach [6]. It involves an iterative process: first, the language model generates an output; then, a critic model (which can be a trained model, external tools like a code interpreter, or other specialized tools) provides feedback on this output [![(b) Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback](image3)].

The feedback from the critic model is then used by a separate refine model to improve the output [![(b) Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback](image3)]. This iterative cycle of generation, feedback, and refinement continues until the output meets the desired quality or a predefined number of iterations is reached [4]. External feedback is often incorporated when an LLM's self-feedback isn't sufficient. [12].

This approach has been utilized in various applications, including question answering, reasoning, code generation and toxicity detection [1]. This can ensure factual accuracy in tasks like summarization [3], and has been applied in diverse methods, see `image4` [![(Post-hoc correction methods)](image4)].

In summary, the 'Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback' strategy enhances output refinement by using external assessments to iteratively improve the generated content after its initial creation.

The `filter-then-rerank` paradigm utilizes templates to convert candidate labels into question options [6]. For the "Contact.Meet" label, the relevant template is found within the description of how event triggers are defined.

The template for "Contact.Meet" is described as follows: "The word {evt} triggers a MEET event: two or more entities come together at a single location and interact with one another face-to-face." ![Template for Contact.Meet event](image5)

So, the prompt template used for the label 'Contact.Meet' is, "The word {evt} triggers a MEET event: two or more entities come together at a single location and interact with one another face-to-face.".

RAPTOR utilizes two distinct querying mechanisms: Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval [7].

The **Tree Traversal Retrieval** method navigates the tree structure layer by layer [11]. It starts by selecting the top-*k* most relevant nodes at the root level based on cosine similarity to the query embedding [8]. It then considers the children of these nodes, selecting the top-*k* nodes again, and repeats this process until it reaches the leaf nodes [8]. This method allows for controlled specificity and breadth by adjusting the depth (*d*) and the number of nodes (*k*) selected at each layer [9].

![A. Tree Traversal Retrieval](image3)

In contrast, the **Collapsed Tree Retrieval** method simplifies the search by considering all nodes in the tree simultaneously [10]. It flattens the multi-layered tree into a single layer, bringing all nodes to the same level for comparison [10]. This method evaluates nodes collectively across all layers to identify the most relevant ones [11].

![B. Collapsed Tree Retrieval](image3)

The difference between Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval is that Tree Traversal Retrieval goes through the tree layer by layer, while Collapsed Tree Retrieval looks at all nodes at once.

The goal is to identify the best fine-tuning method for maintaining high joint goal accuracy on the "Hotel" domain specifically after the model has been expanded to include a new domain.

Looking at the results of domain expansion experiments, there are different strategies compared [2, 3]. The table comparing fine-tuning strategies shows that the base model (BM) initially achieves a joint goal accuracy of 58.98% on the Hotel domain [6]. After fine-tuning on 1% of new domain data, three approaches are compared: Naive fine-tuning, EWC (Elastic Weight Consolidation), and GEM (Gradient Episodic Memory) [6].

Among these, Naive fine-tuning significantly degrades the performance on the original four domains, dropping the joint goal accuracy to 36.08% for the hotel domain [8]. Fine-tuning with GEM maintains higher performance on the original four domains after fine-tuning [8]. Specifically, when fine-tuning with GEM the performance only drops to 53.54% [8].

The data clearly indicates that among the fine-tuning methods tested, Gradient Episodic Memory (GEM) is the most effective strategy.
![Joint Slot Except Hotel](image6)

The fine-tuning strategy that resulted in the highest Joint goal accuracy for the "Hotel" domain after domain expansion was GEM, with 53.54%.

The Chameleon model utilizes a supervised fine-tuning (SFT) strategy as part of its overall training process [3, 5]. The SFT dataset is crucial for aligning the model and enhancing its capabilities, as well as improving its safety [3].

The SFT dataset is categorized into several types, including Text, Code, Visual Chat, Image Generation, Interleaved Text/Image Generation, and Safety [2]. The statistics of this dataset are detailed, showing the number of samples, tokens, and images for each category.
![Chameleon-SFT Visual Chat](image5)
This dataset balancing is important during the SFT stage to ensure high-quality alignment [11]. The table shows the variety within the dataset. For example, "Visual Chat" includes 15.6K samples, 19.4M tokens, and 16.7K images, while "Interleaved Generation" has 16.9K samples, 35.8M tokens, and 30.7K images [5].

During fine-tuning, a cosine learning rate schedule is used, with a starting rate of 1e-5 and a weight decay of 0.1. A batch size of 128 is maintained, with sequences up to 4096 tokens [10]. Dataset instances consist of paired prompts and answers, which are packed to maximize efficiency [10].
![Chameleon uses a uniform architecture trained from scratch in an end-to-end fashion](image2)
This approach facilitates mixed-modal from inception and incorporates a uniform architecture from scratch in end to end fashion [9].

In summary, the supervised fine-tuning dataset statistics are directly related to the Chameleon model's inference strategy by providing the categorized and balanced data necessary for effective fine-tuning, which in turn shapes the model's ability to handle various types of inputs and generate appropriate responses.
